description:
We needed lunch, so randomly picked this place.  It was still fairly early, having just opened so there wasn't a line yet.

I ordered a bento with chicken katsu and vegetable croquette.  It was good and filling, and not too expensive at $11.49 (includes soup, salad, and rice).  Nicely fried and tasty.  However, it took more than 20 minutes for the food to come out.  I understand the items I ordered are fried, but that's still too long of a wait.
author: Karen L.

description:
They have a rather inexpensive set for $11.49 or something like that. In that set, I got the curry rice with the pork katsu. (I wanted to get curry rice with shrimp tempura, because I just had a feeling that their pork katsu would be subpar, but I was told that the shrimp tempura only comes with 2 shrimp.)

The curry was bland, far more diluted than any other Japanese curry I've had. Funnily enough, they have squash in the curry. The rice was also mushy; personally I'm okay with that, but if I'm not mistaken, that's a no-no for Japanese cuisine, and it's also a waste of fine Japanese round-grain rice. The katsu was also dry and bland on the inside.

For some great curry with katsu, I'd recommend Guru Katsu in Mountain View.
author: Albert Z.

description:
Being in Japantown, there are so many other choices you can go to eat and due to unfortunate circumstances- being hangry being one of them. Decided to dine in at Kui Shin Bo since waiting in line for Marafuku and having crepes for lunch was not an option.

The small shop is dimly lit, not in an intimate or calming way, it's a bit run down and lacks in natural light. There were a few people dining in and was seated in the awkwardly quiet shop. Wanted just a bit of food to get blood sugar back up and be on our way, touring the city and opted for the "pick two" lunch with Curry Rice and Chicken Katsu. The lunch came with salad and miso soup. 

The Curry Rice was pale in color, lacking in flavor and vegetarian. You can probably have better-tasting curry from the premade packets from Japanese grocery stores. The Chicken Katsu was equally as bland and the batter fell off the dry, unseasoned chicken. Even dipped in the curry, both flavorless did nothing even with that combination. Salad was okay, basic mix with a sweet dressing.

Service was a bit slow and prices here are cheap, however, you are definitely getting what you pay for here ... maybe even less quality for what you are paying for, tbh. HARD PASS.
author: Janet N.

description:
What the hell is this?!?!? Build your own Sushi?? They got lazy with making up dishes for their Menu, the owner was probably like.. "uhh.. F it.. We're just going to shove some rice and put assorted fish meat on top and give it a made up name. I bet Chirashi Zushi doesn't mean anything in Japanese. You made me pay for $18 and assembly is required?! Thank god it's Friday, coz if I get food poisoning, at least tomorrow is the weekend.  The fish is luke warm, and the roe is stale and dry.  The yellow tail taste like it came from the Can, very salty - taste like cured meat from a Can.

If you've been trying to lose weight, this place is a great way to do it.. I can already predict, I'll be spending a lot of time in the toilet tonight. Not to mention the food poisoning I will probably get for the next few days.
author: Patrick T.

description:
Our server was a kind and older man. He had no help, serving the whole place by himself. He looked overwhelmed and overworked. He took a little longer than normal , the table behind us got so mad demanding free food or walk out. Chill ppl. Really flustered him. Anyway expect for a long wait and time to be served. 
Good food tho. Worth the wait.
author: Michele L.

description:
Today's order:
* Sake Ikura Donburi (8.9/10)
* Wakame Udon (9/10)
* Bento
    * Chicken Teriyaki and Vegetable Tempura 
      (7.8/10)

Story time:
I had a hankering for sashimi and that want was met! We came here because the reviews were good  but when we found the restroom looked very dim and empty. Despite our uncertainty we decided to trust the reviews and went in. That was a decision we did not regret! My order, the Sake Ikura Donburi (salmon sashimi and roe rice bowl) tasted fresh, yummy, and left me with a more than satisfied feeling. The sushi rice was also well made. The Wakame Udon was a dish I have never tried before. The broth was clear and appeared to be very plain but despite looks it had a full taste and did not disappoint. The bento was overall pretty standard but the chicken teriyaki surprised us by packing more taste than it appeared to as well. I would recommend coming here for a delicious and not very costly Japanese meal!
author: Dillon T.

description:
Super Gaijin here.

Kui Shin Bo is all about inexpensive Japanese comfort food. She aint pretty nor fancy but she serves up the cheap goods.

Located on the 2nd floor of J town  KSB reminds me of a Japanese Denny's ( they have a little of everything). 

From Rolls, Ramen, Donburi, Yakatori, Tempura, Okonomiyaki, Udon and more. You get a little of this and that. Nothing is amazing but is adequate. As the saying goes Jack of all trades master of none!

Sushi rolls are actually well constructed with okay fish...prices are great.

Donburi bowls are classic and tasty. Even the Karaage and Takoyaki are well fried and flavorful.

Ambiance is pretty funky and not the best ( there is a certain smell here which isn't great) Service is so so.


But if you are hankering for cheap Japanese comfort food....this is your place!!
author: David G.

description:
Kui Shin Bo is a cute little Japanese restaurant on the corner of the second floor in Japan Town plaza. Every time I went by there is a line out, so yesterday I finally decided to try it out. We went for an early dinner so the line was not long, we got seated pretty much right away. For such a small place, they have a huge menu. Pretty much anything you can think of in Japanese cuisine you can find it here. They have appetizers, sushi, sashimi, ramen, udon, and rice dishes. I got the Shio Ramen with mild spiciness while my friend got the Hamachi kama; we also got the nigiri combo to share. The broth for the ramen is nothing eye-opening, but the chashiu was pretty good. The nigiris are so-so, not much to comment on. The service was rather slow, they didn't take our order until we had called them like 3 times and the food comes out pretty slow as well. 

 

Overall, I have to say this place is not one of the places that wow'd me and made me feel like I have to come back again, but the wide range of selections is definitely a plus.
author: Rachel G.

description:
This place is very small.  My friend and I came together during a weekday afternoon (arouns 2:00pm) after the lunch rush so we got a table quickly.  They have a good lunch deal for approximately $11 in which you choose two items off of a list.  The meal includes miso soup, rice and salad.  I chose takoyaki and tonkatsu.  The tonkatsu was crispy on the outside and moist/juicy in the inside.  The takoyaki had nice bites of octopus.  My friend ordered the sushi burrito and the volcano roll.  The portions were large and the fish tasted fresh.  

The servers were very nice but the service was a tad slow.  Maybe it was because there weren't a lot of servers that day.  I would come here again and rate this place a 4.5/5.
author: Hien N.

description:
When you're in Japantown, you have to get Japanese food, right? With so many options, my boyfriend and I picked Kui Shin Bo. We were not disappointed! Despite some of the reviews I have seen for this restaurant, we loved it! 

We arrived at Kui Shin Bo around 6pm and it was already pretty crowded, but we were seated right away and got the last available table. They have a little self-check-in iPad station if there is a line. Waters came quickly and so did the menus. Boyfriend and I both ordered the chicken katsu and vegetable tempura combo plate and ordered two appetizers of garlic edamame (we LOVE garlic and these had our breath kickin' for the rest of the night) and chicken gyoza (so hard for us to find and nice because the boyfriend doesn't eat pork, but they also offer veggie gyoza too). 

Appetizers arrived quickly but then the entrees took a little time but it was getting busy and we didn't have a problem waiting. Once our food arrived, the portion was actually pretty big! And for only $12 for the combo! Chicken katsu, vegetable tempura, rice, salad, and miso soup! They even gave my boyfriend and I an entire bottle of katsu (plum) sauce which is awesome cause I always order extra! Chicken was moist, tempura was crispy and overall their food was delicious! 

In conclusion, staff was friendly, service was quick, food was affordable AND tasty AND a good sized portion! It's small inside but super cute and makes you feel like you're in a little restaurant in Japan. We'll be back here soon!
author: Anissa R.

description:
The best sushi I tried ever!! Thank you :)
Volcano, family roll and tempura Shrimps on photo
author: Elena F.

description:
I usually stop by Mifune Don for a quick dinner at Japantown, but when it gets very busy, Kui Shin Bo is a great alternative since they have a pretty extensive menu very similar to Mifune Don consisting of ramen, sushi, donburi, bento boxes, and okonomiyaki to name a few.

I stopped by and had my usual Tanin-Donburi (Tender Beef and Egg over Rice), though here they refer to it as Niku-Don.  The beef and egg were hot and steamy and had great flavor from their dashi broth (http://bit.ly/2pU3CqZ).  It's a proper Tanin-Don just like the one at Mifune Don and that's a great thing and I would definitely come back again for another bowl!

After one visit, I'm already a fan of Kui Shin Bo.  The menu is extensive, service is quick, and the food is comforting.  Next time I hope to try out their Okonomiyaki and other Donburi.
author: Rodney H.

description:
Cold evening. I had my heart set on sushi - despite that there was something that was much closer and not sushi. A newer neighborhood for where we often congregate, I found myself slightly lost. This is the problem of having friends you know from 20 plus years ago, you tend to revert back to that person you were back then, you let others make decisions for you when it comes to food because you didn't care about food back then. So I was led, as I was often led by him back then, we came to a restaurant that he was familiar with and I was not. It's a typical cafe style restaurant with two locations, one near where he used to live, which I think was the main reason he chose this place, one in Japantown, which was the one we visited that evening. 

This restaurant has been in the city for sometime, I think the menu is fairly basic, not your usual fancy pants new Japanese cuisine, it has all of your stables: sushi, rolls, sashimi, katsu and teriyaki. The dinner menu reminded me of the 1990s or early 2000s of San Francisco, taken as a whole felt rather nostalgic, as we've been friends and had eaten sushi together since late 90's. We ordered the meal like we would back then, a bit of everything: sashmi, katsu and teriyaki. Food came rather quickly, the soup and the salad to boot. I also had my eyes on cold agedashi tofu which I thought was a decent appetizer.

The restaurant felt quiet on a week night. At 7:30 only a few locals trickled in to grab a meal. We sat together as we would often do, being both left handed helped. He said that he's taken his sister here to eat, and she had liked it. I think it's the sister who had lived in Japan. The service was fast and non fussy, the quality on par with what you'd expect, and the price extremely reasonable. A person came in to try to order something but the kitchen was closed, I heard the server say. They are strict on closing time.

The fog was rolling in. It's one of those typical winter San Francisco evenings. We ate quickly and quietly, leaving just before the very last person. I am content and satisfied.  It might be the food, or the company, or a little bit of both.
author: Victoria E.

description:
I'm wavering between 3.5-3.75 stars, but rounding up to 4. The prices are reasonable. The food is presented nicely and tastes fresh, but it's somewhat bland. Service is quick and polite. We arrived at around 5:30 PM on a Thursday evening. Overall, nothing really blew my mind about this place and I'm not sure I would come back. But nothing was really wrong either!

Sashimi Cucumber Roll (entree): 4/5
The cucumber wrapped around the sashimi could be a liiiiiiitle thinner. The sashimi tasted really good! It comes with a light garlic/soy/green onion dipping sauce.

Shabu Shabu (entree): 2.75/5
Really the only flavor here is salt. It does advertise as a light broth, so it's only fair. There's a good amount of beef pieces in it with plenty of cabbage and onions as well. Comes with rice and three dipping sauces. 

Gyoza (appetizer): 4.5/5
Light, crispy, and served hot! Comes with some dipping sauce. 

Shrimp Tempura (appetizer): 5/5
Very light batter and very crisp. This was my favorite of all the dishes. Comes with your typical veggies and has 2 shrimp tempura.
author: Melanie W.

description: This is a good, solid place in the Japantown East mall. I had the bento box with Chicken Katsu (very good) and Shrimp Tempura (strangely wet in between the fried batter and the shrimp); it came with the standard miso soup, salad and rice. My daughter had their Nigiri Combo, which was fine. The staff we encountered were very friendly, and it's clean inside. I would go back to try more. They had a big menu with a huge selection.
author: Florence A.

description: Too bad ...Advice to the boss was denied .Beef too old ，takoyaki balls are all flour......
author: Sophia A.

description: My friend and I came here for a late lunch and although the place is very small, we didn't have to wait to be seated. I ordered the Black Garlic Ramen. It was really good, but there wasn't much black garlic in it at all. The broth was tasty but not as rich/creamy as some of my favorite ramen bowls. The service was great and had no issues being served or asking questions regarding the menu. Overall, I would come back to Kui Shin Bo.
author: Alexis T.

description:
Had the b5 shrimp tempura burrito roll. It was very tasty. 
Overpriced at $10.99 and it was very small. The Flavor was a burst of different seafood and spices   
It was quick for lunch, and delicious but burrito portion was too small for the price. 
Conveniently located in Japantown East mall upstairs.
author: David C.

description:
First time here tonight for an early dinner. The place is small with limited seating but it isn't crowded with a long waitlist like its neighbors miguzo and the new ramen spot. 

I give it a solid 3 stars. We enjoyed everything we ordered and will likely come back.

Agadashi tofu (3/5) wish it was just a little more crispy and there was more sauce

Caterpillar roll (3/5) the right portion and they had equal amount of eel on each piece 

Sake ikura donburi (4/5) fresh salmon sashimi and ikura. So much fish and so much sushi rice.
author: Tiffany L.

description: Affordable sushi inside Japantown. I like the volcano roll and the salmon mango roll was yummy. The tempura was high quality. The black garlic ramen was okay but not best.
author: Juan V.

description:
You know those days where you wake up grumpy and everything seems to go wrong? This place managed to flip that mood over. There's just something about going to a quiet place where you're treated with genuine kindness and then getting excellent food.

Plus look at this and tell me you don't want to eat it right now.
author: Elizabeth F.

description:
I'm not complaining about this place...in fact I think it is a cute, hole in the wall in J-town.  Tucked off in the corner of the "other" building above Daiso, it feels like you could be in Japan while eating, staring out the window in fact.  My one favorite part of this place is that you can put your name in queue via Yelp!  So you don't have to stand around the entrance waiting to hear your name called.  You can wander around and shop while waiting to be seated!!

The food during this busy Sunday afternoon was okay.  We had ramen, some karaage, and cucumber salmon/tuna roll.  I would say everything was good.  Flavors were not bad.  But perhaps not something I would drive across the Bay for.  However, I could imagine this to be my got to place if I lived right nearby.  It's not too expensive and again not having to literally stand in line like many other places in J-town is a big plus.

Try it out.  Tell me what YOU think...
author: Cary L.

description:
Okonomiyaki had a good amount of seafood and was oh-so-satisfying. Definitely had a really good homecooked feel to it. 

Sashimi felt a bit thinly cut, but their tray was also pretty large. The salmon had a slight fishy taste to it, which overpowered the butteriness. The tuna was on the hard side of things, no real taste to it. Yellowtail had some yellowtail flavor, but was also a bit hard.

The unagi nigiri was a good size but felt like the rice to unagi ratio was a bit high. Unagi was almost a bit bland.

The amaebi nigiri was fine taste-wise, but the meat looked like it was falling apart on the rice...not sure how that happened. Again a bit more rice to fish than I would have liked.
author: Nicole H.

description:
Years ago back in the 2,000's I went to the venerable Benkyo-do- Japanese pastry shop to hang out & have their refined version of fresh strawberry Mochi that was plush, soft, silky. The wife of the chef-owner of Kuishimbo- was there. So when I asked the other Japanese customers who made Benkyo-do- their local hangout where I should dine, they all pointed to the proprietress who told me how to get to Kuishimbo. 

Kuishimbo in Japanese means glutton. I liked that name since that describes me to a T when it comes to eating delicious food & drink. I walked in & sat at the Sushi bar where Chef Kiyotaka presided with a steady eye & steady hand. 

I had an excellent Omakase style meal of Sushi & Sashimi although Kuishimbo also offered a wide variety of cooked Japanese food . Since I was very curious about everything Sushi, he even showed me how to make a Mukimono butterfly from a slice of bright orange carrot with his deadly sharp knife which he presented to me at the conclusion of the elegantly presented meal. Truly a 4+ Yelp experience the many times I went there. 

I went back in 2012 and found out that he & his wife had sold the restaurant to another owner. The Kuishimbo I cherished had disappeared. I wish Chef Kiyotaka & his wife well & are happy wherever they may be. 

I went back once to the new owners, and the Japanese flavours are a bit off. The subtle flavours that distinguish Japanese cuisine are not quite there. Sorry to say I will not return since the culinary competence of the old Kuishimbo by Chef Kiyotaka is missing.  The Kuishimbo of post 2012 is 3- Yelp stars for at least making an effort.
author: Gary I.

description: Avoid at all cost. Mediocre sushi. Asked to remove cucumber. I got a roll where half of the pieces hd it and half did not. Sushi in general is not that good as well as other dishes like Takoyakiw
author: Luca L.

description: This restaurant was a little hard to find because I'm used to the West side of the mall and this is on the East side (a different building altogether). Otherwise it was a good experience. Lunch time wasn't too crowded on a Wednesday afternoon, which I appreciated. There's complimentary tea and tons of food options to choose from. I was so hungry, I wanted to taste everything on the menu. I decided to try one of the specialty rolls and went with Rock & Roll. I liked it a lot. The fish was nice and fresh. For lunch I went chose the Ten-don, shrimp & vegetable tempura over rice. My friend was craving the Oyako Don (chicken in chicken), chicken w/egg over rice. We both enjoyed our meals. Now that I know how to find this place I'll be back!
author: Ali R.

description: Went there for dinner on a Saturday. There is a clipboard hanging near the door with a wait list and you can't leave the area since they just call your name when your table is ready (they don't text/call you). The food was pretty okay - definitely not bad but not amazed either. I enjoyed what I ate which was tonkatsu w curry. Most dishes were under $15 and gave good portions. They could work more on their flavors but still good enough for me to go back
author: Theresa H.

description: This tiny place was very satisfying and pretty cheap when it comes to eating out. I had the agedashi tofu, the curry udon, and the volcano roll. The tofu was good but I think it was blander than I would have liked. The curry udon is super homey and hits the spot when it's what you're craving. The volcano roll was filling and was very satisfying. Sometimes sushi rolls can get overwhelming with a certain type of flavor, but that wasn't the case for this roll, you wanted to eat it forever even when you are so full
author: Anh T.

description: The food was great except the wait time is really long to get the food. It took around 15-20min to get our food. The service was really nice though. The tonkotsu was a little dry and the breading fell off easily. But the lunch deal is worth.
author: Monica D.

description:
I've been there twice and it's been hit or miss. The wait range from half an hour to an hour, but there's plenty to do nearby to kill time.

The good:
- okonomiyaki was pretty yummy!
-black garlic ramen was pretty tasty
- Chicken teriyaki was pretty good

The so-so: 
- seaweed salad was not very good
- takoyaki was good but pretty average 
- tonkatsu ramen is decent but pretty average
- one of the House rolls with tuna and seaweed salad was just OK

This place is average and has a lot of options. The service is friendly and quick. If you don't want to do the long wait at other restaurants, this is a good compromise for a decent Japanese dinner.
author: Jacqui C.

description: Tried this for lunch today, pick 2 items with soup, rice, and salad.  Value was very good but quality was not quite there.  I had the california roll and teriyaki chicken and my partner had the ramen and takoyaki.  Food was tasty.....
author: Kelly C.

description: Awesome! They have some of the best reviews in Japan town and there is a reason! Everything was fresh and we ordered everything from edamame to sashimi and something from the grill side to! Great sushi, friendly service, we will be back!
author: Morgan D.

description: If you're coming here for curry..DON'T. Came here since this place got 4 star and ordered a Katsu curry. Everything was great until i tasted the curry.. or should i say watered down curry. It was just disgusting. I've been to many Japanese restaurant from SF all the way to east bay. I have to say this is the WORST curry I've ever had in my whole entire life. And just when i thought things couldn't get worse, i tasted the katsu, it was literally like fried paper, super thin, hard and chewy. I left after having couple bites of my food, couldn't finish it,it was a torture. I can't speak for other food here it might be great that's why they got a 4 star review, however, for curry, it's just nasty. Save your money and go to other places, I'm sure any other restaurant here in Japantown has better curry than here.
author: Jasmine Y.

description:
A small shop inside the mall - caters a variety of Japanese food. We had the chashi ramen and the vegetarian ramen along with some chicken katsu. The ramen was good but not outstanding. The katsu was not very memorable either but was a sizeable portion. 

 Usually, there's a pretty long wait so remember to your name down before walking around the mall.
author: Anand R.

description: I wish it was a few more notches up in quality than a Safeway sushi stand, but it isn't. Service is very good however. I might, just might go back.
author: Kevin F.

description: The customer service is bad.The beef we ordered was too old. The boss attitude was bad toward our advise. Unpleasant experience there. Not worth it ...
author: Shuzhen Z.

description: Slowest ever on customer service. If u plan to eat in this establishment u better make sure u have NOTHING to do the whole day. Food is regular. For all the waiting, sushi became tiresome.
author: Rhemely F.

description:
Food is alright but depends on what you order. Flavors are very Americanized. 

Came here on a Friday night and it was pretty steady. The location isn't in the most visible part of Japantown. It's located above the Daiso on the 2nd floor. 

We ordered a volcano roll, cold soba with tempura, and chicken katsu with rice and curry. The menu is pretty extensive and they have pictures for most of their popular items.

The volcano roll was good. It has a shrimp tempura inside and it's covered in crab meat and tuna. We ordered it to share and still had 4 pieces leftover to take home. 

I just wanted a side order of cold soba, but they only had the set meal with tempura. The soba was alright. The dipping sauce for the soba was super salty and not very rich tasting. The dipping sauce for the tempura tasted like water. The servings for the tempura were generous. Lots of veggies and 2 pieces of shrimp.

I'll prob pass on ordering the chicken katsu again. The portion was like fried chicken nuggets instead of a cutlet. The curry tasted alright, but it's not similar to the curries they normally serve in other restaurants. It was also filled with a lot of fillers like potatoes and carrots. 

The flavors aren't bad, but there are more authentic tastes in Japantown.
author: Junella T.

description:
Not much wrong with this place, but I definitely didn't find it like a 4 star restaurant. I came with family and we ordered several dishes, including a ramen. For ramen, I'd say any of the specialty ramen shops around are better; we liked the Marufuku ramen and also the suzu noodles ramen more than here.
One dish that stood out for me was the Okonomiyaki, since I don't see that dish often. It is sort of a Japanese omelette. I would have this again if I went back. Know that it is savory and might make you quite thirsty afterwards, but that's how the dish is anyway.
I would say this is a family type restaurant, not so much a place to impress, but I wouldn't mind going back some other day and perhaps change my idea.
author: Mimi Y.

description: Found this spot while we were walking around Japantown. When we first got there, it was completely empty so were seated quickly. This place is small but the menu has sooooo many amazing options! The manager came to us and suggested their special and we were sold ! 2 main meals, miso soup, rice and a salad. The food came very quickly and it was really good. I give it 4 stars because even when we were done, it took a long time for them to clear our table and give us the bill. Other than that, I definitely recommend this place !
author: Janice D.

description:
Terrible, terrible!! This establishment really has fallen down in their service and their quality of food. Just went to lunch there today and the wait was very slow for the food to come. For some reason, the other three tables that was seated later than my table received their food first! All the tables were occupied, but there was no sense of urgency by the staff. The kitchen staff and the service staff could be seen chatting and food was just trickling out. Only one dish at a time would be coming out and alot of time between each dish of at least ten minutes each. Water was never filled or offered for refills. Any service needed after you ordered required flagging down the two servers.
 Food quality was awful as the chicken katsu was tepid in temperature and the bread coating was too crunchy and no taste to it. I could tell it was old chicken that was used to make this dish and the tempura batter was old. Salad was bland even with the dressing and it was was obvious that the lettuce was not fresh. Beef Teriyaki was chewy in texture and also tasted and looked like day or two day old meat was utilized to make the dish. The only saving grace was the Vegetable Tempura which was fresh vegetables and fried to perfection. 
 Seriously not trying to impress their customers or expecting fresh ingredients as necessary for their food. Only expect mediocre or poor food expectations and slow to non existent service by the staff if you chose to dine here. Expect better food and service at one of the other food establishments in the area.
author: V. P.

description:
Food was very delicious and amazing prices. The manager suggested the daily special and it was definitely fulfilling. 

Fortunate for us we walked right in and got a seat. No wait time at all. 

Highly recommended.

We'll definitely eat there again.
author: George D.

description:
Love the name......Kuishinbo*....... Hello! Talking about me? 
*(kuishinbo in Japanese means a person who loves to eat excessively or a glutton)

A great Japanese chef once owned Kui Shin Bo back in the early 90s. His forte was cooked food and not so much sushi. I have not been back after he sold his business. While visiting Japantown during the Cherry Blossom festival, I was more than thrilled to revisit Kui Shin Bo out of sheer nostalgia. Golly, nothing in the interior has changed since the 90s! It looked pretty rundown today. Kui Shin Bo is tucked away on the 2nd floor in an unobtrusive corner of Miyako Mall. I was anxious to see if Kui Shin Bo can still be regarded as a hidden gem. Yes, it is still hidden in that forgotten corner but sadly, I wouldn't now call it a gem.

We started off with the healthy Kinpira Gobo ($5.49) where root veggies like gobo (burdock root) and carrots were first julienned and then sautéed and simmered in sugar and soy sauce. Gobo had a distinctive earthy flavor giving the dish some sweetness and a nice bite. Kui Shin Bo's version was decent if a tad dry. For the health conscious, gobo is loaded with minerals and high in fiber. (3/5)

Feast your eyes on the Chilean Sea Bass Butter Yaki ($17.99). It is guaranteed to make any fish lover drool! It looked like it was delicately pan-fried and perfectly grilled judging from the flakey meat and the beautiful grill marks on the fish. The taste was divine. It was mild, rich and buttery. The fish had a slightly charred crispy surface without losing lusciousness. The presentation though appeared slipshod like the fish was plopped haphazardly on a disorganized bed of bean sprouts and corn. Nevertheless, this was a great complete dinner as rice, miso and salad came with the entrée. (4/5)

Okonomiyaki ($10.99) can be addictive.  I just had one a week ago at Izumiya (also in Japantown) and I was craving for it again. I was hoping that Kui Shin Bo could come up with a better rendition. For the uninformed, okonomiyaki is a savory and hearty Japanese pancake griddled with everything from cabbage, pork and soba to fried eggs and "dancing" dried bonito flakes. Goddamn! I was hard pressed to pick the winner except to say Izumiya has the edge only because Kui Shin Bo's version was too gloriously lathered in sauces, the sauces being Worcestershire or Tonkatsu sauce and Kewpie mayo. (3/5)

Tenzaru Soba ($10.49) is a wonderful summer dish that is light and refreshing. It combines 2 well-known Japanese dishes: Shrimp Tempura with veggies and cold soba (buckwheat) noodles served on a bamboo dish. My big gripe was the tempura batter was too heavy as the goal is a light, crisp coating so that the pieces of shrimp and veggie don't absorb oil when fried. By the way, you can forget about Miss Manners when eating soba. It is perfectly OK to slurp your noodles loudly to your heart's content! (3/5)

The servers were courteous but faintly aloof. The interior requires a makeover as all I can say is there is no ambiance. If all you care about are the low prices and a little better than mediocre food (with the exception of the Chilean Sea Bass), then Kui Shin Bo is your place!
author: Geoff G.

description:
Great choice for lunch! We ordered Tonkatsu ramen, volcano roll and tempura combo for three of us. We love the ramen here because the soup isn't salty at all! We finished the everything we ordered! 
Thumb up for the service, very fast!
author: Yoyo L.

description:
Salmon mango roll
Deep fried California roll
Volcano roll

Extremely delicious. Neat and clean. Staff was kind and attentive.
author: Ty N.

description:
I came with a group of 12 and was amazed that we were all able to be seated (albeit split into 2 tables of 6) since it is a small little restaurant in the corner of the mall. 
I ordered the chashu ramen, which was a very large and filling portion of noodles. It was pretty good and made me very, very full but definitely wasn't the best ramen I've ever had. The soup could be richer and the toppings (egg, meat, etc.) could probably be a little better prepared. Still, I emerged from the restaurant completely happy and satisfied, especially considering the very reasonable price I paid for this meal.
author: Vicky Y.

description:
Got the rainbow roll. 

Rice is kinda mushy but well seasoned. 
More rice than fish. 
Pricey for what you get. 
But at least it's kinda tasty.
author: J P.

description: I think the food is slightly overpriced compared to other places with lunch specials. However, the beef teriyaki and curry rice were delicious. The beef teriyaki was sweet, chewy and a had a smoked smell to it. The curry rice was also sweet, but nicely balanced with the carrots and potatoes. The servers were very nice and attentive. The presentation of the lunch special on a tray was aesthetically pleasing. I was seated as soon as I arrived and my order was taken not too long after. The food came out fairly fast within ten minutes of my order being placed. I am rating this place four stars because while the food is good, it is not overly spectacular.
author: Linh N.

description: We were on the wait list for a long time, but that's because the restaurant is pretty small. The food was good, but if there's a wait, I would pass on it. I got katsu with rice, it was good but nothing to rave about.
author: Emily X.

description: I couldn't recommend this little restaurant highly!!! Great service, delicious food, it's menu is so broad and affordable prices. Way better than any other big restaurant in Japan Town! Love it!!!
author: Mari L.

description:
First, this is not authentic Japanese, which wouldn't be too bad if the restaurant didn't advertising as being "authentic Japanese".  I guess that should have been a tip for me.

Now putting that aside.  The food is ok, it's on the cheaper side, but not great.  Its typical asian fusion food, kind of Japanese, but kind of just "sushi burrito" stuff, but mostly just meh.
author: Kent I.

description: Always worth the wait. I've been 4 times now and everything is delicious! Best place to eat in Japan Town.
author: Brittany C.

description:
Fairly long wait but this is a small restaurant. We started with the curry rice which was my favorite dish of the night. Great seasoning and very savory. Next we had the volcano roll and the crunch roll. Both was tasty and was ample size. 

Down side was service was kinda bad, no water refills or tea refills during the entire 35 minutes we was seated. For only 10 tables or so, that's not an issue a joint this size should have.
author: Moses H.

description:
Returned for the 2nd time at Kuishin bo after many months!Visited with two friends, one of which was vegetarian. Between the 4 of us we shared:

- Sashimi platter (salmon, tuna and saba)
- vegetarian roll and vegetarian okonimiaki
- volcano roll
- caterpillar roll
- baked salmon roll
- philadelphia roll

This place is consistently great. Amazing vibe and energy in this cozy little sushi place in Japan town. Food is fresh and tasty. Service is efficient, fast and friendly. Prices are great too. Plenty of vegetarian options as well - our friend was very happy with her choices! 

Will always return to Kui shin bo :)
author: Heliana M.

description: Yum! Decided on this place because it was #1 on yelp for sushi in the area I'm visiting & it's walking distance from the hotel I'm staying at, score. We tried the edamame, vegetable tempura (watch out for the bananas!!), beef teriyaki, miso soup, volcano roll and the chicken tempura roll (not pictured). Overall, it was a great first meal in San Francisco.
author: Magdalene L.

description:
4 stars for the food
1 star for customer service
3 stars for wait

Came here on a Friday evening. Had decent reviews so decided to try it out. They have a waitlist where you have to put your name down and number of people in your party. We thought we wouldn't make it that long but our wait was 40 minutes long. We got tempura and few rolls. Food was good but then at the end since they were busy they were almost rushing us. At one point while I still had few sushi pieces left and wasn't paying attention they literally took away my plate and cleared the table.
author: V V.

description:
Amazing place! Great food! Great service!
The sushi is amazing! It's really really good. The service is also very good. And the prices are fair.
author: Tomer G.

description:
Even days after eating this place, my views haven't cooled on this place. Both food and service were bad.

First there's a line so we put our name down. When we check in half an hour later, boyfriend asks a worker for an estimated wait time. Worker asks what's our name and then says we're next. 5-10 minutes pass and a different worker comes out and calls a different name and seats them even though we were told we would be seated next.... Whatever, miscommunication, it happens, we're seated 10 minutes later.

We ordered that roll that has fish inside and the cucumber outside which was okay. Its good if you're going Paleo or trying to cut out rice. Now the dish that I do NOT recommend: ama ebi shrimp for $13ish dollars. I'm so upset at one the price and two the explicit sub par quality. The shrimp tastes as if it was just boiled in garlic water and then served with the chopped garlic. I'm so mad they ruined an ingredient that is naturally delicious.
author: Mimi T.

description:
Came here for Saturday lunch and it took about 15 minutes to get us seated. 

It's found in the corner above Daiso in Japantown. 

They serve pretty much most of Japanese food from sushi rolls to nigiri to ramen to okonomiyaki and everything in between. 

They have pretty good deals too if you want to try a mix of everything. I got the special where you can try 2 entree items and they come with miso soup, salad, and rice. I got pork tonkotsu and sanma shio (broiled mackerel). The special was a LOT of food...and did I say it was only $9.99??!! Such an awesome deal. 

My bf and I also shared a Caterpillar roll because we wanted to try the sushi too (and also because I love eel haha). 

Overall, unbeatable prices for the amount of food that you get.
author: Natascha E.

description:
The food was okay. This was a little Japanese restaurant where you can grab a quick meal, minus all the fancy mancy Japanese decor and stuff of a larger full sit-alone restaurant. 

I ordered off the special $9.99 menu that they posted right by the entrance. I chose the tonkatsu and ramen choices. These tasted just okay -- super average. 

The tonkatsu was a tad dry imo, but it was edible nonetheless. The ramen was pretty sizable. If you order the ramen as an entree, the bf noticed that you def get more -- he was eyeing a chick and her noodles as she sat across from him. The few pieces of meat that came with the ramen was hard, not tender at all. Perhaps it was left over meat as it had a tough consistency. 

Kui Shin Bo is located on the east side of the Japan Center on the same level as Ichiban-Kan.
author: Andrea M.

description: This place is excellent. It's small so the wait can be long but the seafood is very fresh and the sushi is fantastic.
author: Min M.

description:
Newest discovery:

Black Garlic Ramen!

Goodness
author: Monkey B.

description:
I got the lunch set where you get to pick two items and it comes with rice, salad, and miso soup. I opted for the tonkatsu and agedashi tofu. I wanted the curry rice, but they ran out and it was only 2pm. The tonkatsu did not disappoint -- very crispy on the outside but still tender and juicy on the inside. The tofu was really bland and even when I tried to slather it with the sauce, it just wasn't good.

Service wasn't bad. The staff were all really friendly and I got my food in a reasonable amount of time.
author: Elain T.

description: Was looking for something to eat in Japantown, San Francisco. Came across this place on Yelp because it had four stars. Wait was super long, but we could put in our phone number and get called when our table was ready. I explored the rest of the shopping area during our wait, which made it seem much shorter. We were seated nicely, and the male server took our orders, coming off a bit abrasive to me. I got my food quickly and the udon was delicious. Tempura was great, and the sushi tasted nice. However, two friends in my party got their sushi extremely late (to give you an idea my other friend and I were already finished with our meals). The server gave no apologies and handed us our food rudely, which is why I give this place four stars. An okay experience, but I won't be back due to service and wait time.
author: Caitlin H.

description:
Inedible. Don't eat here.

We were pretty surprised this is 4 stars and the highest rated place in Japantown, especially since the recent reviews were all pretty bad. But we were pot committed with the wait and lured in by the cheap lunch special.

Just skip.

I ordered the ramen and garlic noodles for lunch combo, expecting one would be bad but the other was edible. Unfortunately, I ended up with both being inedible.

Ramen: no flavor, basically a clear broth, with pork meat that was chewy and unable to break down into pieces

Garlic noodles: so, so, so dry I I had pour the ramen broth into the noodles to make it go down.

This is probably the worst meal I've had in all of 2017. Skip this place!
author: Lilly D.

description:
Overall I liked this place! If you don't know where to take your friends this place is fine but I will say the wait was fairly long. I was more impressed by the number of options they offered and wish I got to try more things! The portions are also pretty big.

Specifically, the sushi was pretty good although I'm not really a sushi connoisseur. Since you are in Japantown, I can't say for certain you can't find better sushi but they have a nice mix of ramen, sushi, bento boxes, and even sushiritos if you like that.

Overall it didn't take too long for the food to come out despite the fact there were so many people. I will say the wait was fairly long (at least 20-30 minutes maybe longer but I was so hungry I can't remember) so just be sure to take that into account.
author: Augustus Y.

description:
Small little restaurant in a mall in Japantown.  Great place to come for intimate dining experience.

The food was delicious.  We ordered sashimi, ramen and edema me.  There were too many dishes to choose from. 

Highly recommend.
author: Susan C.

description:
Visited this place on a saturday. It was not busy and got two house special rolls (salmon mango roll and baked scallop roll) with sweet shrimp (ama ebi?) on the side. 

Quality wise the rolls weren't that fresh or spectacular. the shrimp meat would come off with the shell when I would peel cause of the lack of freshness..

I definitely regret visiting this place and spending my money here
author: Jennie N.

description: The fish was very old. It was the only time I couldn't eat my nigiri. Ramen broth was okay but the meat in it was not great.
author: Salar H.

description:
We came here today for dinner after visiting my dad nearby.  We enjoy the 12 piece hamachi for 16.95 and the tenzura udon with tempura.  Sashimi is very thinly sliced but extremely fresh and high quality.  Udon was portioned small but had good texture.  The tempura was pretty good and we enjoyed the jumbo size shrimp tempura that was almost a foot long.  Everything tasted very fresh.  

Service was amiss as they forgot to bring us the green tea and Coke that we ordered but still charged us for the green tea but the manager gave us cash back for the tea with taxes included so he was honest about paying us back.
author: Lorissa W.

description:
Decent food and nice family that runs it, but the wait is long and if it's busy, the wait to get your food is even longer. Ordered several bentos... in the bento, you get four pieces of kaki fry, 2 pieces of shrimp tempura (pretty large size) and if you order an udon or ramen, you don't get your salad, rice and miso. Also, the curry rice is just curry sauce with potatoes and carrots but no meat. Tea comes out of a small pot and is not very flavorful. 

I wouldn't mind eating here again, but I definitely wouldn't wait for it.
author: Anna V.

description: This place is a winner! We couldn't decide on a place so we left it in the hands of our hotel reception who recommended this place. We waited 20 min but worth the wait. Food was delicious! A nice change from all the touristy food we have been eating.
author: Rosanna B.

description: Authentic Japanese food! Little hole in the wall is awesome. We got a few tako nigiri to start off and it was excellent! Moved onto the spicy ramen with chicken and the egg in it was to die for. We also had the rainbow row which was okay. The crab wasn't too great but other than that everything was above average.
author: Kaimi Y.

description:
Food was okay but service was the reason they lost stars. Portions are well sized and I was really full. 

Service issues were that 1) when we were ready to pay the server's were nowhere to be found so we waited an extra ten minutes, then 2) they told us the credit card machine wasn't working and that they would only take cash. Luckily, we had enough cash on hand to cover the meal for all 5 of us, but on the door there were no signs to indicate that their machine wasn't working despite their credit card acceptance stickers. Nor did our server inform us of this when we were seated. Imagine if we hadn't had any cash on hand...
author: Mia L.

description:
Excellent choices of lunch combo: chicken katsu, tonkastu, tempura, rolls... Comes with rice, miso soup and small salad, all for 10.99!
Food is good and staff is friendly.
I've been here few times already and I'll be back!
author: Coralie S.

description:
Really excited to try this unassuming cafe after reading the Yelp reviews. We dropped in at 12noon on a Sunday and was thrilled to find a multi-story parking garage for Japan Place. It was not cheap, but very convenient and we'll organized.

Japan Place has all sorts of fun food and shopping options and I immediately took the the vibe. The lunch specials were a great deal at about $10 a person.

We adored the miso soup, but as other reviews indicated, the Ramen and Udon were meh. The noodle texture was just flat and the broth was not punchy.

However,  the entrees were great. Having real slivers of octopus in the takoyaki?!! Win! Saba Shioyaki with lemon and daikon--awesome. The California Roll was heavy on the crab salad. The teriyaki was on the sweet side. The curry was simple but not exceptional.

Our server was really attentive and sweet--he brought me more daikon when I used it up on my first bite of Saba. 

In all, we are looking forward to returning and trying other entrees.
author: Lu-Shien T.

description: Just discovered this place and it's awesome. Had the specialty rolls ... super fresh and eclectic menu choices. The salmon roll with mango was delish. Highly recommend. Small and cozy. Great service.
author: Kristine S.

description: Chicken Teriyaki was great! Good portion of everything-Vegetable tempura had all my favorites a variety of veggies! The miso soup was perfect in seasoning. We have to take the whole family here next time! It was a $10.99 special for picking out two items out of a large variety of choices. Short wait line if busy.
author: Stephanie N.

description:
This shop is found inside of the Miyako Mall, in the very corner of the 2nd floor. It's a very tiny restaurant, but the service is great and very fast. We also got great recommendations from the waiter. 

As for the food, their sushi was super fresh and for a fairly cheap price. The okonomiyaki was delicious, I would highly recommend.
author: Emily Y.

description:
I enjoy coming to this restaurant every time I am in SF Japantown.
The service, the food, the drinks are spot on. Their Yakitori, Tonkatsu, Karaage is a must. The price is very reasonable.
author: Eric Y.

description: This place has a total of 8 tables so be prepared to waite. However, the food is great.  My dad who is very picky ordered the black garlic ramen and LOVED it. I had some sushi that was great and better than most sushi places we have in San Diego.
author: Michel U.

description:
Went for lunch around noon. Very clean and service was quick! 
Sushi was fresh. All in all, a good spot to go. Would recommend & come back to try the ramen!
author: Zahyra G.

description: They had a nice ambience and the staff is friendly.  It's a cook yourself style KBBQ and you also have menu options not to cook.  We chose not to cook since we were in a bit of a rush.  Had the bulgoki and it was just ok.  Came with rice and the meat and a bunch of shredded cabbage. The meat was seasoned nicely and it was sweet.  They also gave us soup but it was so bland.  Needed some salt or seasoning.  The sides were not bad and kimchi had good flavor.  My favorite sides were the tofu and kimchi.  It's a bit overpriced for lunch and portions were a tad on the light side.
author: Gillynn C.

description:
The star of our meal is the ramen and udon.  We tried the agedashi tofu and the sashimi platter in which you can choose 3 fishes.  The tuna and salmon tasted tender and fresh but the snapper had scales.  It wasn't clean well.

Ramen had a decent flavor and udon soup was delicate.  This place is popular too as we waited over 30 minutes to be seated and we got there later too.

Service was friendly.  We would come back for the ramen.
author: Kayla N.

description: Fantastic sushi for a great price.  Friendly staff and good operations for a wait line courtesy of using yelp
author: Erik H.

description: We came here for lunch with my parents on a weekday and they were offering some great lunch specials. The restaurant was not full so we were immediately seated.  The owner here was really nice and helped explain to us some dishes in Japanese that we didnt understand. He even offered his recommendations of the specials and he did not steer us wrong. The food here was good and portions were reasonable. Service was friendly and attentive. We'd definitely come back here.
author: Janet E.

description:
Quick and friendly service. We came in when their closed sign was outside but still got seated. We ordered a ramen, two rolls and a sushi burrito. 

Food = a-ok
Service = friendly and quick (they probably wanted to clear out customers)


Would I go back? We didn't see the special box set for $9.99 until after our order so will come back and check it out.
author: Sam Y.

description:
Came here to check out their $9.99 lunch special that everyone keeps Yelping about, and their 4-star Yelp rating in Japantown lured me in. They have a lunch special everyday where you can pick 2 items from a white board menu - they all come with miso soup, salad, and sometimes rice (if you get ramen or the garlic noodles you do not get rice). We also ordered their karaage as an appetizer.

I ordered the combo with the tempura squid and saba mackerel. Mackerel was nicely grilled and super flavorful - the skin and meat were delicious. No need for sauce at all, though I did squeeze the accompanying lemon. There are bones, so be careful when eating. Luckily I eat a lot of non-filet seafood that I'm used to picking out bones.

I was a little surprised at the squid tempura, but I guess the super Filipino in me expected little squid tentacles deep fried in batter. Instead they looked more like onion rings, where the squid was cut up into rings, tempura battered, and fried. It was a bit oily and honestly nothing amazing, even with the tempura sauce and dashi. The squid was chewy and kept separating from the batter.

My friend ordered the tonkatsu and garlic eggg noodles - in his case, it didn't come with rice because of the noodles. The tonkatsu was awesome, the pork moist and crunchy and I loved how they gave a bottle of tonkatsu sauce to go with it (some places just don't drizzle enough). The garlic egg noodles were surprisingly good! I thought they'd be pretty plain (I see garlic noodles at a lot of Bay Area places), but they were very garlicky and had some minced pork in it too. They also came with some hot chili garlic sauce on the side, which went really well with the noodles for an extra kick.

Sadly, their chicken karaage wasn't too special... somehow the chicken was pretty dry, and I can only describe their breading as "chalky" with potato starch. Weird. I wouldn't recommend as there are other places that do a really good job at karaage, and this just isn't one of them.

Another thing that is weird about this place is the food delivery - when it is ready, they will bring it to your table. Some people like their food fresh, but it's a little weird when your companion's food doesn't arrive at the same time, and it can feel impolite to eat it right away while your friend is still waiting. 

I noticed this with other tables where a guy started eating his food, and i was under the assumption his companion had not ordered anything. About halfway through the first guy's meal, his friend got his meal. The same happened with me, but luckily my friend is a super fast eater anyways... so it was probably better that I got a head start. Just keep that in mind if you're in a large group, since this was consistent at the other tables I observed.

Anyways, definitely recommend this place for lunch while exploring Japantown. The food is good (assuming you order the right things) and cheap... but they still accept credit card. ;) I'd say it's more of a 3.5, but rounding up because the price is right.
author: Alyanna C.

description:
I gave it a five stars just because....

1)The owner and the staff are very friendly!
2) foods are so bomb!
3) I am very satisfied with my ramen ( I ordered black garlic ramen) and my first time trying ramen ( don't judge me).
4) our order came in less than 15 minutes 
5) I love the decor there.

Bonus: this restaurant is next to Ichiban Kan store 

I'll definitely coming back! They have another location on Lombard street. Address: 1424 Lombard street
author: Sharon W.

description: This place is pretty good and affordable. It is located in the Japanese mall in japantown. It's a little hole in the wall in the corner of the mall, with about 10 tables. We were a party of 3 and at first they sat us at a 2 person table and pulled up a chair on the side. They wanted us to get seated right away which we appreciated. They handed us menus and got us some water. However, when a 4 person table opened up, they offered us to move to be more comfortable. My boyfriend ordered he Mad Spicy Ramen, I got a caterpillar roll, and a sake nigiri, and my sister got the dynamite roll and the real California roll. Our only complaint is that the ramen came out instantly and the rolls came out about 25 minutes later. They did forewarn us about the timing but i just don't see why they couldn't wait to start the ramen when our rolls were being started to allow for them to come out at the same time. Otherwise, the food was delicious. The ramen was good, but wasn't super spicy like we were hoping. We got a Level 2 spice. It seemed like they only use chili flakes to make the soup spicier. The caterpillar was sweet with a touch of honey, which I like, but others may not, so beware. The dynamite and the real California rolls were good; my sister has no further comments. Overall, would recommend!
author: Kathy H.

description:
We love this place!  After a long trek from the Golden Gate Park to here and exploring Japantown, we were hungry!  We saw the advertised special for a two-item meal that came with miso soup, rice, and salad for $9.49.

Here's what we ordered:

1) Kushi Katsu and Beef Teriyaki - The Kushi Katsu, which was sea bass, was fried to perfection and not fishy tasting for me.  The teriyaki was very savory as well.

2) Chicken Katsu and Curry Rice - Very excellent combination.  I loved using the curry sauce with all the other items we ordered.

I don't believe you can go wrong with the $9.49 deal.  We enjoyed our meal here and will probably return during our next trip.
author: Loretta C.

description: Delicious fresh sashimi and sushi rolls. Great prices & prompt service. Give them a try in Japantown!
author: Lisa J.

description:
At this point the wife and I have been out of our Sunday Pilates workout for about and hour. We were hungry, but as is the case when your mind is clouded by fatigue and hunger food decisions were nigh-impossible to reach. Then one of us opened Yelp, searched for sushi, and found the reviews and pictures agreeable. Plus, on-call, we found there currently was no queue.

We ordered the special, a couple of appetizers, one too many sushi rolls, and left sated and satisfied.

Four Stars!
author: James G.

description: Not sure how this place has garnered an overall rating of 4 stars. The only thing I can think of is there was a change in ownership or chef. We were craving sushi and made the mistake of coming here. The fish was very low quality, and the rice ball for each piece of nigiri was unnecessarily large. Prices would be ok...but given the poor quality of the sushi, I'd say they are much too high. Maybe we should try some of the cooked dishes, like kushikatsu or okonomiyaki...but I doubt we'll be back to do so.
author: Amelia C.

description: It's OK. The sushi is a lot like I'd expect from a buffet. It's sliced very thin and there isn't a lot there. Also a bit over priced. There are plenty of much better sushi restaurants in the city, I wouldn't bother with this one.
author: Joshua C.

description:
Whenever I find myself craving ramen, I pay a visit to Japantown. Actually I just so happened to be shopping at Daiso, and my cousin wanted to have lunch, so I decided on Kui Shin Bo. We arrived around noon and put our name on the small clipboard out front. We were third in line and waited for about 20-25 minutes for our name to be called. FINALLY! For the next hour, you could see the line slowly accumulate outside, so definitely get here early if you plan on eating at this particular place.

I'm not sure if this restaurant is slow, understaffed, or they hand-make their ramen noodles one by one... but once we ordered, it was another 20-25 minutes until I got my ramen. My cousin's food came first, which was a shame because obviously he was going to wait for my food to arrive, but it took forever. I had ordered the spicy ramen, which was delicious and worth the wait. The staff here is also very friendly, so it was a pleasant experience, but perhaps I was feeling impatient that day.

The food here is reasonably priced, and they have an impressive selection of food on their menu (including specials) so if you are venturing to eat in Japantown, I would add Kui Shin Bo to your list of considerations. Just make sure to build in time to wait and eat.
author: Stefanie C.

description:
Love eating at this place! Every time I visit SF for sushi I usually come to this place. The food is excellent and the staff is friendly. The only downside about it is how there's usually a long line and it takes quite a bit of time to get seats. 

In terms of food, there's a lot of variety to choose from and the pricing is not too bad. I'm always pleased with their service and food so the prices are never an issue

Favorite thing about this place is their vegetarian sushi! Since I'm allergic to seafood, I can't really have an real sushi and this place has some pretty good vegetarian sushi. Looking forward to coming back!
author: Michelle C.

description:
We came in at around 6:00 and we got in pretty quickly despite Japantown being more crowded than usual because of the cherry blossom festival. The three of us were actually put at the sushi bar, which wasn't ideal for conversations but we didn't want to wait for a longer time. There seemed to only be one waitress going around to all the tables, which worked because the restaurant was so small. The service was quick, and food came especially quick for us because the sushi was being made in front of us. 

I have to note that the menu has a LOT of different things. They have sushi, udon/ramen, donburi bowls, yakitori, and more. We got the nigiri combo, salmon mango roll, and baked scallop roll. They each had 8 pieces, which was good for 3 people to share. The sushi tasted fresh and well made, especially the nigiri combo. I liked the salmon mango roll as well because of the sauces. To be honest, I didn't really like the baked scallop but that may have been personal preference. 

I never really eat in the East Mall, so it was great to try this place. I liked the food and area a lot, and it's a place I would return to in Japantown.
author: Jocy G.

description: This place takes forever to make sushi we waited like over 40 minutes for two orders, one roll and one sashimi order. The customer service was horrible, not once did the waiters check in ask if we wanted something else or more water or drinks.
author: Kali A.

description:
Before I went off to college, my friends and I would frequently eat here because the food was good and the prices were cheap. Two years later, we decided to revisiting the place and unfortunately, the restaurant is not the same as before. 

I understand the menu prices being raised and all due to this bad economy but my friends and I were more disappointed with the quality of the food.The main reason I liked to eat here was for their bento box speciality but after this last visit I probably won't come here as often as I use too! 

Their bento box speciality includes rice, miso soup, salad and then choosing two items from a list of many options. I decided to go with my favorite chicken teriyaki and shrimp tempura. The shrimp tempura and miso soup where as good as I remembered them being. But the chicken teriyaki was one, smaller portioned and two, the sauce tasted thinned out and watered down. 

I didn't order anything else from the menu but from previous experiences, I think their bento box speciality is there best item on the menu. Though it is not the same as before, the bento box is still a good deal compared to the other items on the menu. I don't think their ramen or udon noodles are worth the try especially compared to other restaurants in Japantown that make better bowls for the same price. I also think their sushi rice for their sushi rolls  is not every good because it's too mushy. 

The restaurant is kind of small and it does get crowded and cramped inside when it is at it's capacity. Though it's not the cleanest restaurant; the customer service here is very attentive and welcoming.   

Bento box $10.99
author: Justine J.

description: Sign in on the clipboard outside! The wait wasn't too long, but since the restaurant is small... It was kind of awkward sharing a 4 person table with another party of 3 that had their friend on one of the edges. The okonomiyaki was pretty good as was the ramen. The chicken karaage could have been better. A pretty good spot, but there are so many other choices in Japantown I'd rather go to.
author: Melisa M.

description: Great little Japanese place right in the Japan Center. Many Sushi/Sashimi/Nigiri etc. options and other Japanese food too. Very casual place and my favorite out of the places I've tried in the area (so far). There's a Sushi/Sashimi combo that's not that expensive and you get a whole lot of fish.
author: Gil S.

description: I tried the Bento box lunch special with pork ribs, and Shrimp tempura, the quality of the food and service was excellent,  this is a very small cozy little restaurant, reminds me of the type they would have in Japan, the serving / portions seemed kind of small, but this is just a lunch special, I havent tried the sushi yet, maybe next time , this is a great place to grab a quick lunch.
author: Mr Bolo B.

description:
The $10 lunch special seemed too good to be true. (Hint: It was)
The girlfriend ordered the tonkasu and ramen. The Tonkasu was dry and overcooked and the ramen seemed like it was really half a portion. The ramen broth was super plain and it didn't include a egg or even half an egg. Look at Andrea M.'s picture and compare it to the other ramen there. 

I can't remember what I ordered. It was a assortment of fish. It was ok. 

Would I come here again?
Nah. Nothing stood out and I've experienced better.
author: Steven D.

description:
New favorite in Japantown.  The food is a great deal, and delicious with good portions.  My mom is not a ramen person so when she ordered it I had to try it too.  The flavors are all so spot on. 

The California roll was delicious and fresh.  I would highly highly recommend splitting an okonomiyaki with someone.  

Lunch special pick 2 for $9.99, can't beat that.  It's a small shop so you might have to wait and the staff is all very kind and great, but when it gets busy it can be hard to get a tea refill.  

Nevertheless nice to find a great lunch spot.  You'll definitely leave happy and full.
author: Kate G.

description: Chose this place because it had the highest amount of stars on yelp for Japantown and not really sure why. The service was really attentive and they were very friendly, but the food wasn't that great. We shared some rolls and the chicken katsu lunch special. So the chicken was good, but a small portion. More rice than anything. Also had rolls and they were disappointing. Too much rice and not enough flavor. The best one is the volcano roll, so get that if you want to try a roll. We ordered three rolls and didn't like the other two, so we actually had enough leftover to make one roll. The rolls can be quite pricey too. Almost forgot to mention the vegetable tempura. Unfortunately, the vegetables were oily and not crispy at all. Quite disappointing and wouldn't go here again, but the servers were really nice.
author: Sherille S.

description:
I liked it. Yup, not a highly polished gem, but it serves up good food. Going at a time (late lunch 2:30PM) when many of the restaurants in the "east wing" (of Japan Town) were closed Kui Shin Bo had many customers.The decor is basic, but reminded me and my lunch partner of joints in Japan. The waiter was superb making helpful and good suggestions, he was accommodating and responsive; yup he was NOT a "20 something" with multiple piercings and TATS. Those service folks usually reserve themselves for joints that have that sleek "modern" look with "house music" thumping.

My lunch bro had the Nabeyaki Udon, I had Chirashi. Both were good renditions, the best in Da City  ? ... ah no, good as a joint in Japan ?... ah no, as good as it gets in S.F. Japan Town at 2:30PM during the week ah YES. Ah so. Near Ichiban Kan in case ur in the dollar store mood.
author: Matsuo U.

description:
This place is appalling dirty. It's a hole in the wall, with a hole in the wall taste. 

If you have had a mediocre sushi before, then this place should be illegal. 

Orders salmon family, salmon & unagi nigiri and had a bite of each. That's it. 

The salmon had no flavour, the preparation process was weak and felt like a junior chef just didn't come into work and they served the salmon as is. The rice had no structure and relied on the mushiness to keep it stuck together. It's not of quality and definitely a tourist trap at Japan Town. 

If you come from a place with decent sushi, you will not like this place. 

Front of house, clean up yourselves and brush your nails, or just do something.
author: Tony P.

description:
- Sashimi Cucumber Roll (3/5) - Probably wouldn't get it again. Looks pretty but mainly just tastes like cucumber. I'd rather get a sushi roll or just sashimi by itself.

- Seafood Okonomiyaki (5/5) - Would get again. 

- Hiya-Yakko AKA the chilled tofu appetizer (4/5) - Added a nice balance to all of the other fried and grilled oily dishes we ordered. The 

- Grilled cow tongue (4/5) - Just slightly burnt when we got it but still delicious
author: Kim L.

description: Holy schnitzel been here 30mins and I ordered a tonkatsu ramen. No sense of urgency around here
author: Eric Z.

description:
This is in the mall in Japantown. It's super busy, has great prices, and I loved the ramen.

Black garlic ramen - had grilled pieces of meat inside. It's not the typical fatty chashu but I actually enjoyed it better. The broth was delicious, savory, and a great blend of flavor. I got it spicy and it had the right amount of kick. Seemed to have fever noodles that a normal bowl of ramen does though. Everyone was jealous and wished they got my dish.

Pros:
Casual atmosphere with cute low wooden seating. 
Great prices!
Lunch packages at great prices - huge options of things to pick from
Great sushi
Great ramen

Cons:
Always crowded - waited 20 min at 2:30 PM on a Saturday
Slow-ish service
author: Linda S.

description:
We enjoyed it. Arrived today about 11:30 am and two other tables already had diners almost done eating so not sure when they open.

We had spicy edamame which we like a lot

Loved the seafood pancake. Arrived at table still sizzling

The mackeral  sushi was excelle t  as well as the unagi donburi bowl

We had bento boxes with shrimp tempura, veggie tempura, fish katsu (we ordered chicken but got fish, but it was ok cause the fish was awesome) and California roll.  They also came with soup and salad

The portions were very generous and we ended up taking leftovers home
author: Foodlover B.

description:
Excellent quality food.
Fresh high quality fish.
Best fried soft shell crab I've had in years-- so fresh and flavorful!
Only -1 star due to really hot room w no A/c...
It was the hottest day of the year in SF and normally no a/c anywhere in SF is a non issue but -- it was stifling hot.

As long as you go on a non "nuclear hot" evening you can expect wonderful Japanese food at excellent prices and quality
author: A K.

description: We ordered a bunch of rolls that were really good. The fish was really fresh too. However, the service was pretty bad because we were waiting very long for the sushi to come out. When it finally did my family had finished their food. The server had some serious attitude too. Overall I didn't like the vibe of the place and there are better places to try in the mall.
author: Connor H.

description:
Based on the Yelp reviews I had high hopes to eat here. Unfortunately, it was a mistake. This restaurant does not serve authentic tasty Japanese food. It is large portion tasteless food just to fill up your belly. 
I would not recommend this place for dinner. It may be fine for a quick lunch but that is all. 

The thing that stroke me the most was that next day, I ate at the cheesecake factory at union square at the top of Macys and I paid less!!! Can you believe it? It tasted much better, and the environment was much pleasant as well. 
So, long story short, don't look for a tasty Japanese food at this restaurant.
author: Burak S.

description: Business trip, stayed in a hotel nearby. Ordered spicy ramen, and it was great. The menu was extensive, wish I could have more time to try some other dishes.
author: Svetlana D.

description:
I ran into this place after buying a few nick nacks at the store next door. Out of the gate you will notice that it is super tiny! I'd say maybe a total of 8 small tables? Maybe even less. I did notice a Yelp sticker as I was walking in, so that alone gave me some confidence. 

I was greeted immediately upon entering, and let the waiter know that I was taking it to go. Not looking at a full menu, I decided to play it safe and ordered their Shrimp Tempura Roll. As I sat down, my waiter walked over to hand me a menu.  He mentioned that they make a variety of sushi burritos. BOOM! I've never had one, so I figured this was a good time to pop my cherry! I asked for his recommendation, and he called out their "Crispy Shrimp Bo'rrito". All I could picture in my head was a big ass sushi roll on steriods. 

The shrimp was nice and crispy, and the wasabi siracha sauce was top notch! My only complaint is the shrimp to rice ratio. It felt more like a rice burrito with a side of shrimp. But when I was able to experience that balance of shrimp, rice, cabbage, cucumbers, shallots, and green onions...it didn't disappoint. 

Side note:
This place is about the size of a 1 car garage, but don't let that sway you. They get it done like the rest of the big boyz out there!

Conclusion: 
I will definitely be back to try their other sushi burritos!
author: Robert H.

description:
This is located in the mall on the second floor! It's pretty small inside with about 9 or 10 tables that could seat from 2-6 guests.

I ordered from the lunch special which was the bento box. I got the teriyaki chicken with california rolls. It comes with miso soup, rice, and a salad. The salad I wasn't too much of a fan but the rice and miso soup were good! I think the serving size was good for what we paid for. My friend got the teriyaki chicken bowl which also came with rice, miso soup, and salad. 

It was a little busy when we got there with about four tables left open. The staff was friendly but quiet. The owner was really nice and took our order on a tablet!

Definitely will be back!!
author: Kalani M.

description: Ramen, Saba, gyoza, & nigiri  love love love  please stay cute, modest and friendly! My family loves this place! And how convenient Ichiban & Daiso shopping nearby #kuishunbo #Japantown #sf
author: Jessica J.

description: DO NOT GO HERE!!!! The food is subpare quality. Felt like we were at a cheap buffet. The WORSE sushi we EVER had!
author: Lynn T.

description: Pleasantly surprised by this homey, low key Japanese restaurant in one of the Japantown malls.  The waiters were very nice and patiently explained the menu.   Good deal on a lunch special.  My wife had perfectly cooked shrimp tempura and tofu.  I had the tonkatsu ramen.   It was delicious.  I ordered it 2/4 spicy and still found it pretty spicy. I was feeling pretty wimpy until the young Turk at the next table started coughing a d choking over his ramen.  I would definitely go back.
author: Joel S.

description: Delicious food! The price-quality ratio is good. Most main dishes are around $10-12. They have cheap and some more expensive sushi and a great variety of dishes. Though it was a pity they sold out of unagi don (eel with rice). The chairs might be for most people a bit low and hard, but it's all about the food. With just 4 not so big eaters we spent $80 including gratuity. So you will surely be satisfied eating here!
author: L C.

description:
Decided to check this place out strictly based on Yelp reviews. It's a good neighborly spot that has a large menu with lots of choices. My Japanese mother ordered Nabeyaki udon and my sister ordered the pork ramen. They both said their meal was fine. I ordered the Volcano roll which was fine too. 

I was excited to try out the Vegetable Okonomiyaki because that is my all time favorite thing to eat, but I was disappointed. It tasted fine, but didn't have the okonomiyaki taste and it was not authentic at all (no fish flakes on the top either). Mifune Don across the hall has a much more authentic version. 

Overall, not a bad place to eat, probably would try another place before I come back here. The service was fine although it was obvious the server guy didn't care to be there at all and just needed to do the bare minimum.
author: Elaine Tiffany P.

description:
My favorite place in Japantown! Best value and best service hands down.

I recommend the Garlic Egg Noodles and Tonkatsu with the hot tea. Very satisfying for lunches and dinners. 

The staff is incredibly kind, attentive, and quick. Really love this place and is my go-to place.
author: Vi T.

description: Food was mediocre, the fish honestly seemed a bit stale, both of our dishes were brought out at different times, and service was poor.
author: Jay P.

description: I was excited when I saw cucumber sashimi roll, also they have the Katsu don.  I got Katsu don first, i was very disappointed with Katsu don.  It was my least favorite katsu don.. it was very dry and not have much sauce, eggs, and onions.  Then I got my cucumber sashimi roll, it was just ok..
author: Megan J.

description:
We decided to try Kui Shin Bo after visiting the Daiso store located downstairs.  

The location is attractive and we passed by a couple of times before deciding to go inside.  We are not disappointed.  Our decision to have dinner here was a good decision.  

We found the food and sake to be agreeable, so we decided to go back another time.

The selection of sushi was varied and we enjoyed the selection.
author: Veda F.

description: It was delicious! Fast and friendly service. Nothing pretentious, just good food with very reasonable price.
author: Ebru C.

description: Teeny tiny hole in the wall in the Japanese mall in Japan town. Had spicy tuna roll, the veggie roll and the spicy crunchy roll. Also had two types of nigiri. The nigiri was delicious and fresh. The rolls were also really good but the veggie roll was very average. They have a large variety of sake too.
author: Ashmita V.

description:
On a cold drizzly summer day... miso soup and the sushi brightened up my day. 
Super fresh and tasty. Then owner was helpful and gracious. Nice to find a good Japanese restaurant open ALL day too
author: Julia A.

description:
Came here on a Sunday with the boyfriend around 2:30, we put our names down and had to wait about 30+ minutes.  The location was very small and there was a group of 11 in front of us, which made the wait extra long.  

We ordered the super dynamite roll, tonkatsu ramen, and tempura udon.  The food took about another 30 minutes to come, which was a while, but made sense due to the crowdedness at the time.  The tonkatsu ramen came first with no tonkatsu in sight, however the dish itself was still pretty tasty.  The sushi came next and was pretty good in my opinion (took off the fish eggs though.  It had a good amount of crunch and flavor, but you could still taste the sashimi.  The tempura udon broth was a bit too wakame flavored in my opinion, I usually like it with more dashi flavoring.  However it was still good, and the tempura was yummy.
author: Nina W.

description: Loved the food here. It is authentic, and so freaking good. We got the ramen, seared steak, and salmon and it was perfect. I really enjoyed the setting inside Japan town, and the service. I really felt like I was in Japan, from the service to he authenticity of the food. Check this place out for all Japanese food, from sushi to ramen and beyond!
author: Ross S.

description:
I have a friend that loves this restaurant. He says it's "the best Japanese restaurant in the city" 

There are 2 reasons why someone keeps coming back to the same restaurant:
1. they love the food for taste
2. they appreciate the value

This particular instance definitely falls under bucket two.
