I like ordering the daily specials, 2 items that come with miso soup, rice, and salad for $7.50. It definitely leaves me full too, the price didn't worsen the size or quality of food.
author: Vanessa L.

description: I love this place. I always get oyako don(chicken simmered with eggs over rice) and their lunch special, which is two entrees with miso soup and rice. The staff is always nice as well.
author: Yuri R.

description: good experience. It is in a mall, which made it little tricky to find it. But the owner is really nice and friendly. Their daily special was good. If you want to try different food, try the daily special, it is small portion but cheap, which can make u try various food.
author: Monica X.

description:
thinly sliced pork with beansprouts and scallions dinner plate was tasty but a tad on the oily side.

my salmon shioyaki dish was just ok -- too dry for even my liking.

i probably won't come back.
author: Helen Y.

description: I went back this week and the sushi rice was terrible. It was far too sweet and the hamachi tasted off. :-( Hmmmmm....
author: Jacqueline A.

description:
Substandard Japanese fare in a tiny hole in the wall with seats built for smurfs. Miriam W.'s 5'2" and said the chairs were too small for her. I'm 6'2". Half my body can't fit under the tables, let alone attempt to sit in the chairs...

Service is anything but pleasant. The owner is a tiny woman with a perpetual scour who reminds me of the quintessential Lunch Lady... it's a mixed blessing when she hands you her mediocre food and then leaves you alone for the rest of the meal. There's absolutely nothing special on the menu. Anything you find here, you can find at a dozen other places within a five minute radius.

Two stars for the forgettable food and uncomfortable eating environment, minus one for service and the fact that the meal cost me over $2500 -- I had parked on Geary and came back an hour later with my car window smashed open...

Thanks for dinner, but no thanks. Every single Japanese restaurant in the building is better.

P.S. Never park on Geary. The projects are across the street, and there's constantly broken glass up and down the boulevard, and even though the police station is literally a few blocks away, they do nothing. My car alarm was going off, cop cars kept driving by. I flagged them, standing in the middle of the street, they wouldn't even look... So I called the station, and they said, get this, your better bet is just to drive home and go to the station near your house to file the police report....! Can the police be any more useless and irrelevant? Moral of story: park in the underground structure or north of Japantown.

P.P.S. "Kuishinbou" means "glutton" -- but in this instance, it should mean "abstainer."
author: Perci N.

description:
WOW! Their spicy tuna roll is revenge-on-the-white-people hot! By the time I was done with the cone I had such a post nasal drip you would have thought I had just come off a weekend bender with Nick Nolte*:
http://www.throwmyshoe.org/images/nicknoltedui.jpg

Of course it was questionable whether or not we were even going to get food to begin with. The waitress whose English wasn't the best didn't suffer questions (or fools) lightly. There were a couple of times that we had questions about the menu and specials and finally just ordered them on blind-faith. We ordered from the specials menu, the regular menu, and from the sushi chart. 

The specials menu for the day were actually complete meals which we didn't know til the food arrived, but it worked out great. It was a grilled halibut, noodle soup, rice ball and pumpkin tempura. The pumpkin was phenomenal and wasn't overloaded with tempura. Just lightly battered. 

From the regular menu we ordered yellow tail sashimi. It. Was. Like. Butter. Some of the freshest fish I've had in a bit. Our only complaint is that you couldn't break up your order of sashimi into groupings of two. Full orders consisting of 6 or more pieces only. 

Finally from the sushi chart we ordered tamago and unagi. Both were spot on. The tamago especially. Instead of being place on a bed of rice like most nigiri, the tamago was big enough to have a pocket in the center where they placed a small ball of rice. Cool presentation. 

I hate to round out the review with a negative but I'm gonna anyways. Hot sake only. They need some chilled sake on the menu. There is nothing worse then when your mouth is on fire and you have to drink hot liquids. I guess it was a good thing I had a nice chilled bottle of Sapporo on the table also. Quit judging me. I can drink sake and beer at the same time if I want to.  

(*Nick Nolte does not approve of this review)
author: Bucky K.

description:
3.5 Stars

I dunno how any of these places in Japantown stay in biz.  There were hardly any people around on the east side of the mall.  I was a little leery at going here, seeing they had only one customer in there.  Because Nobu K said it was good, we took our chances.  

Kui Shin Bo has a decent sampling of Japanese food offerings.  Their dinner specials (located on the white board at the entrance) were especially appealing.  Wasn't sure what to expect from the waitress as previous reviewers say she's hit or miss.  That nite, she appeared to be normal.  I ordered the Halibut-kama which came with fried oysters, Japanese string beans, rice and miso soup.  T had the soba tempura.  I had thought about ordering sashimi, but figured I wouldn't overdo it.  I was sad to hear they didn't have a lot of variety in their fish selection.  Never been to a place that didn't have hamachi.  I settled for a sake (salmon) nigiri to start off the meal.

When our food arrived, we were surprised at the portions.  Very good.  I could've split my meal, if push came to shove.  The fish was nice and flaky and the oysters were still creamy.  T's soba was good, but the broth got to be a little overly salty.  The tempura selection was also very good and varied.

The topper of the evening was when this party of 4 enters the restaurant.  Sits down.  Has some tea while looking at the menu.  One of them asks the waitress, "do you have any rolls?  Anything like a caterpillar roll?"

Waitress says "no."

The woman goes on to explain to the waitress that it's her friend's birthday and such.

The waitress responds "sorry, no JIVE ASS ROLLS here."

The party quickly exits.  LAMB.

OK, the last part about the waitress' response didn't quite go down that way, but seriously...who goes into a restaurant for a birthday dinner, without checking out the menu???

Half star for that entertainment.  I wish they just had a better selection of fish.
author: JeFF T.

description:
I was not impressed with the food here. It is edible, but it's nothing special. I do like the fact that they have daily specials. 

For starters we got the gomaae, gyoza and deep fried ika. The deep fried ika drowned in katsu sauce was my favorite. The gomaae was definitely tasty. I didn't like the gyoza at all. Blah.

Last night I got the deep fried hamburg with omrice and a mini spaghetti salad. Came with miso soup and green tea. The hamburg was good and luckily, they left the katsu sauce on the table (came with another appetizer) so I kept pouring it over my hamburger. But the omrice was a bit bland. 

Eugy got the sanma dinner. It looked really good, but due to my allergy to fish, no sanma for me. 

The teriyaki menu looks awesome. Though unimpressed with the food, I'd like to come back here to try the teriyaki. It's supposed to be made the traditional way. 

The woman isn't overly polite, but don't take it seriously. She's just that way. She does say all the niceities, but you can tell it's just methodical.

edit:

Eugy made a comment that you need a native. That's so true. There is a menu on the wall in Japanense and I'm sure there are more items that can be ordered that aren't on the menu. So you need to either 

A) be able to read japanese so you can order from the wall menu

or 

B) be able to know what you want and be able to speak japanese so you can explain to the waitress what you want
author: Jen D.

description:
I'm new here in town, but if Kui Shin Bo is what four stars means in San Francisco, maybe I should have moved back to Tokyo instead.

I showed up with two friends on a Thursday afternoon, and we were the only ones there. Which made for fair service, but the food was bad: halibut fishy enough to convince those uninitiated that "surimi" is Japan's answer to "Fancy Feast®", and a sashimi selection spotty enough to make one wonder if the 2030 post-overfishing apocalypse had already reached Post Street.

Perhaps I'll try again someday at a more regular hour, but with all the other choices in the area, perhaps not.
author: Jed S.

description:
The food is really good.  The way the egg is half raw half done for the oyako donburi (egg and chicken with onion flavored with dashi over rice) is superb.  All egg on top of oyako donburi and katsu donburi (same thing with pork cutlet) should be half done and dreamy looking but its rarely perfectly served that way.  

I had the vegetable zosui (rice soup).  Its just rice in soup, really, but I love it.  Its not porridge which is stewed forever.  They just dump rice in soup.  No one makes zosui at a restaurant except for here...maybe because it's so easy to make at home but I like to eat simple food prepared deliciously.  

I think the lady just doesn't like to kiss ass.  She is really nice to the old japanese people and the regulars.  Her not being too nice doesn't bother me.  Its easy to deal with.  She ignores you, you ignore her.  But I think after a few visits, she will warm up.  That's my feeling about her.  Plus the food is so good, I really don't care.  It's not a hang out sort of place anyways.
author: Wakako U.

description:
Good lunch deal for sure, but that server lady will melt if you throw water on her.

FOOD:~Good bento box deals for lunch. The cod was amazing with ketchup rice.

~Sushi is good, clean, generous. Love it!

SERVICE: the WORST EVER. It's like she just doesn't give a *beep*. She ignored us forever at the door--at least let us sit down! I hope they read this & make a change because service is really important & the food ain't THAT good to make up for it. Just as all the Yelp reviews warned me. In the Yelp section where you vote for "waiter service," I'd say "barely."

DECOR: Simple, Japanesey.

BATHROOM: Out in Kikokuniya Center. Depressing. Far away.

OVERALL: I'd go for lunch again if in the area & craving a good deal for cooked J food, but only if I had a lot of time to wait for that waitress's turtle service. Would've been a 4, but alas the service was next to nonexistent.
author: miss b.

description:
Rock bottom prices ( I wonder how they sustain a margin ), decent quality.
You can be sure to find seating even when all the restaurants @ the other mall are jam packed.
$13.99 for a Halibut collar set meal with the halibut collar double the size of a hamachi kama @ an izakaya joint.  What a deal!
So why are we the only 2 tables there? Location location location?
Is that particular plaza cursed (other than ichibankan?)  Perhaps... but I think attitude goes a long way in attracting / retaining customers.
The waitress, while in no way rude, is absolutely stoic and will not warm up to a conversation, be it Japanese or English.  Also she's not quite flexible with customers' requests such as getting an extra box for take-home.  The atmosphere reminds me of older grumpy Chinese food joints.
I am sure with a friendlier and cordial attitude they can get more business.
author: avalon e.

description:
The minimum amount of stars you can give on yelp is one, but trust me, this place deserves zero.  The food was AWFUL, the service was extremely slow.  They forgot half our order - never brought out my avocado roll although I asked for it twice - and tried to over-charge us.  AND they were out of two things we ordered... that's embarrassing. 

While I was looking at my menu, the waiter came over and asked if he could take it and give it to another table.. huh??  It's not like the place was full - maybe 3 tables sitting, total of 8 people in the place TOPS.  They should definitely invest in more menus!  

When the waitress finally came over to take our order, I told her what I wanted, and then she turned around and started taking the order of another table - completely ignoring my friends and the fact that they might want to eat too.  It was ridiculous.

After they realized how awful their service was, the waitress (whom I assume is the owner) told our table that they had just opened the day before.  Seeing how far back these reviews go, and the fact that I was just there this past weekend, I'm assuming she was lying to us.  

This was HANDS DOWN the worst sushi experience I have ever had.  I will never go back to this restaurant again.
author: Ariel F.

description:
Maybe they serve the bad fish to the white folk----

I realize that not every Japanese restaurant should have great sushi, some specialize in other good dishes that do not revolve around raw fish.  However, if you have 'sushi bar' in bold letters on your sign and have many dinners which include sashimi, I expect the fish to be at least an acceptable level.  I've had better sashimi in Jackson, Tennessee where 90% of the population has never even had raw fish.  The saki (salmon) was the plane horrific. The Edamame did not seem fresh, and for $5 I would hope for a bit better quality.  On the upside- I did like my ginger pork dinner, but this was not good enough for me to go back.

If your in Japan Town, from my experience, I would recommend hitting up one of the other dozen places to eat.
author: Josh M.

description:
OKay so it took a while to figure out what to eat.. and we decided to eat here. Whoo  hoo.

My Dad ordered sake and some fish sushi thing... pretty pricy for a small plate. 14$? not worth it. It was frozen fish too, just thawed out. =| that's not good.

My mom ordered some fish bento thing, and it was pretty big and only for 10 dollars. I say that was worth it!

I myself odered some udon (i have never tried udon so i can't compare it to anything) But i REALLY LOVED IT! it was super tasty. my sister said it tasted plain, but I think that might be why i loved it soo much!

My sister orded some california rolls. tasty. yum yum. only 6 though. (which is standard , i belive?)

The service was pretty nice. There were only like.. 2 waiters i believe? so they were trying to help out everyone at the same time. Very Nice. 

The chairs=uncomfortable. God i hated them .

Overall, service is nice, food is pretty good, price is a little pricy. I liked it though. 

+1 star for the yummy udon! :D
author: Jennifer L.

description:
Had lunch with a friend and two children today -- I'd been here a few times before, but 4-5 years ago.  Still very good food, and reasonably priced.  We all had specials -- somen salad with curry don, and chuka ramen.  It was quite authentic and tasty.

The woman who waited on us was not unfriendly, just busy as it got busier after we came -- and all except the table behind us were obviously native Japanese and having a rousing good time joking with each other.  Must be regulars.  Glad I remembered the place.

I think kuishinbo means 'gourmand' in Japanese.
author: Anna H.

description:
Absolutely the worse restaurant experience ever!!!  Reading the other earlier reviews from last year leads me to believe the management must have changed recently.  Because there's no chance this place could ever get past a 1 star.

Words can barely describe how absolutely dreadful this place is.  But, what the hell, let's try...

When we got in, we had a feeling something wasn't right when it took 5 minutes for 1 of the 2 waitresses to seat us, even though there were 6 tables open.

Then we were seated and it took another 5 minutes to get menus and only after calling the waitress over.

She took our order, as we started seeing people walk out... which did not bode well for us.

She comes back and says, they don't have 2 of the sushi items we ordered, so we order something else.  

We get some of the sushi, as well as the tempura udon we ordered.  The sushi rice was mush.  The udon tasted like it was the packaged type you can get at a dollar store... but worse.  The broth tasted like starchy water.  They must have forgotten to put in the powder.  The tempura was cold and completely soaked in oil.  

She comes back and says they don't have the other sushi item we ordered either.  At that point, we ask her to cancel all of the remaining orders.

We try to eat whatever edible bits we can.  

I got up and asked to pay for the check.  She takes literally 5 minutes to add up our order.  And on top of that, she charges us for the sushi that they didn't have and the other items we canceled.  She takes another few minutes to add it up again... I pay and finally we can end this ridiculousness.

Seriously, don't take a chance.  Don't weigh this review against some of the other good reviews.  Just don't go!
author: Brent S.

description:
So my sister and I were looking for tempura and we had a little extra time to walk around Japantown center. We looked at EVERY menu, prices, choices, etc before we found this place. We decided to go to Kui Shin Bo and it was not at all disappointing. 

Great service, great food, great price... what else can I say? I had the vegetable tempura and the portion was good, plus it came with rice, green tea, and miso soup. I am so glad we went. Got a business card on our way out. 10% discount on the card. We will be back. 

Waiter recommends Burmese food, maybe it's worth a try. Happy eating!
author: Elizabeth L.

description:
This has got to be one of the best kept secrets in San Francisco. Simple, deft Japanese cooking at a fraction of the usual price.  Also, notably, the best steamed rice in San Francisco at any Japanese or any restaurant whatsoever.

The daily specials never fail to be interestingly varied or to please - today for lunch I had shioyaki halibut, miso soup, sauteed bean sprouts, Japanese potato salad, and steamed rice - all for under $10. Beat that!
author: Celeste S.

description:
It's out of the way, and it may well be empty when you arrive, but don't be fooled.  The fish is fantastic!
We were 2 of but 4 people in the restaurant, and all 4 of us were at the sushi bar.  The sushi chef is fantastic - his fish is amazingly fresh, buttery, and delicious.  The nigiri rice is the perfect consistency and flavor, and the slices of fish are of good size and (from what little I know) cut expertly.
Prices are also most excellent - an average of only $3.50 for most nigiri.
Know that the selection is fairly small, however, and this is an authentic place - don't expect a big selection of creative rolls.  (ie, if you're looking for dragon rolls or rainbow rolls or something, go elsewhere.)

I'll also say we had no problem with bad service at all, unlike many other reviewers.  The chef is very attentive and friendly, and our tea was kept full.  In fact, after ordering some tasty and tender taco (octopus), he taught me how to tell the difference between male and female octopi - in females, the suckers are all the same size; in males they vary in size - and that the females are tastier.  He was serving female, of course. :)

So great food, and great prices, in a very authentic Japanese atmosphere.  I'll be back!
author: Don H.

description:
Good food, but bitchy waitress!!!!

I really like the food there but I don't think I'd ever go back to the restaurant because of her very ill manners.  If you're in the service industry, her attitude is far from acceptable.  She doesn't even smile, and us always so grumpy.  That's so bad because the restaurant would be popular because of its fine dishes, but I'm sure lots of customers would feel the same way I did.  

You don't go to a restaurant just to eat.  If the environment of a restaurant isn't good, you don't feel comfortable.  You'd lose your appetite.  I DID lose my appetite when I asked her to bring a glass of water a few times.  I asked her very nicely but she was very rude and took her almost 30 minutes to bring a water. 

If you don't care about the environment and just look for good food, you might like it.  That's my opinion.

Again, to me, even though the food is good, I can't enjoy the flavor of the dishes when a food server isn't nice.
author: Mike M.

description:
How come Yelp won't let me give 0 stars? ;/

We went in b/c they had cheap (5-7 dollars per plate, and 2-4 dollars for rolls) and we were hungry. There were 4 tables (out of something like 12) on a very slow Sunday. We got our food in an HOUR. 

To top it off, the server gave us a dirty look when we started asking when the food's going to come.  She either has a very short term memory loss or must've smoked weed cuz we had to ask 3 times to get chopsticks and 5-6 times for water. I'm no restaurant guru, but i think having basic utensils might make the sales process go a bit smoother.

The sushi-man (well, actually it was a woman) took 20 minutes for 2 orders of sushi... then another 20 minutes for another order. She must've gotten out of the building to go catch a fish, prepare it, and drive back in all that time... I dunno how long it takes to prepare one freakin' order of California rolls. (i.e. rice, crab meat, avocado, and laver).

IN their defense, the sushi lady gave us a "freebie" b/c i guess she could tell we were getting frustrated with the slow service. She said "no charge" when she gave us an order of sushi. I couldn't tell if SOME of the stuff on the order was free or the entire thing was free. I asked her for explnation but she spoke limited english. Despite the fact that she could've asked her manager for interpretation, she decided to answer "no charge, no charge" no matter how many times I asked for clarification.

What's more interesting is how the cook came out to eat his lunch when we, the customers, weren't even fed. To top it off, the head waitress/manager stared at us for last 5 minutes we were there while eating her food.

Food was ok. Price was good.
Service sucked ass.
author: TaeWoo K.

description:
I have not tried Nigiri here, but I tried other regular kitchen dishes, and they are GREAT!

Kaki fries were good, and their best so far was the Teriyaki's. 
I think they have the best teriyaki in the town - although not the best one I had in the Bay. I like how those teriyaki's come on the grills. Chicken was already very good, but the beef T was awesome. However, the teriyaki sauce was a little bit too light, although it seems to be in effort of not killing the beef taste. 

I first went this place after looking at the reviews, and was scared of the waitress, but I don't know. She was pretty nice to us, although she was not the best waitress ever I had. 

When my friend ordered Edamame as "soy beans," she was all smiling and teaching us how to say edamame, and she was smiling that time, too.

She was not the regular Japanese-polite waitress, but she was fine, and I was there for the food, and food was great... 

If I am in J-town for J-cuisine, I would go here. Udon and noodles here is not bad, still pretty good, but there is a better place for Udon in J-town.

Despite the service review you read from other folks, the food is great and it makes me keep going. So, this place gets 4 stars from me.

(I will update the review when I try their nigiri...)
author: Andrew Y.

description:
I just came back from visiting home (the Mariana Islands), eating LOTS of fresh fish and rice. I mean, like, fish just caught, grilled, fried, raw, etc... with just a little salt or dipping sauce. All manner of reef fish, fresh tuna, mahi mahi, parrot fish... you name it.

Having eaten enough delicious fish & rice, during my visit, to last me a few years, my palate has re-asserted itself to delicate seafood/fish flavors. That said, Kuishinbo's saba is amazingly good! A whole side of mackerel, grilled to perfection, and dressed with the lightest squeeze of lemon. My Lord it was a good homecoming meal. Add to the fact my totally non-seafood eating friend asked to try a bite, is reason enough to get thee ass to this place.

Kuishinbo has a good selection of donburi (rice bowl) dishes, and everyday-type Japanese fare. The specials were good, serving sizes were hearty, and our server was charming & casual. One of my friends wanted uni nigiri, but the server advised against it. I like that honesty.

I've never paid much attention to this tucked away restaurant, because I really dislike the lighting/atmosphere inside Peace Plaza. It seemed like it could be a tourist trap, but my perception was wrong. I would not have eaten here if it wasn't recommended. Friends with good tastebuds are the best, I tell you....
author: Antoi C.

description:
Just heard that the chef has decided to finally close the restaurant after January 8, 2009. Well I guess after being here for 20 some odd years he is ready to retire. Best wishes. Maido Arigatoo! Hope another good, sho-chu infusion and aka-cho-chin place might move in, but I guess that is too much to ask for in this high rent mall.
Good sushi chef. Cranky-moody wife. I'm with Toro E. on a review of the place, because it is really too bad the waitress is his wife; he'd have this place packed if it weren't for her moodiness whilst  working here. Try sitting at the counter but the restaurant only seats about 30 at various tables and her vibe is just not what you want to have to deal with also when you pay your bill if she is Mrs. Crankypants that day..humm give her a SpongeBobsquarepants doll, make her wonder what that's all about!!!!!
author: miriam b.

description: Went here on a Tuesday night and enjoyed the quality of the food and the hospitality of the waiter. They're sushi was awesome!
author: Ren V.

description:
if you're a tamago geek like me, you MUST try Kuishinbo's own inside-out tamago nigiri. Out.of.this.world. 

I love how this restaurant intimidates white folks. I also think it's probably because of the location within the Kintetsu Mall is not as centric anymore now since that cheesy buffet finally closed. 

Here's another family-owned restaurant that's been here for at least over 10 years. You know it's the real deal when the waitress [owner's wife] speaks to you in nihhongo. 

Some of the best donburi, udon and seasonal sushi you'll find in Japantown. A sleeper hit!!
author: Tomas V.

description:
This is my go-to place whenever I am craving tori tonkatsu.  this place serves up authentic Japanese food, the chef is japanese.  Although I heard that he recently sold the place to a Burmese owner but continues to work here.  The waiters/ess are not Japanese which is abit off putting when you order something in Japanese and they dont know what it is.   They could improve on this.

They say good food will keep drawing the customers back - in my case this is so true about Kuishinbo.
author: Teresa T.

description: This is place is nice for lunch. You get to choose two items for $8.50. It comes with miso soup and rice. I had the tonkatsu (pretty good!) and garlic noodles with chicken (lots of noodles, get it if you're really hungry). My friend had the saba, which she liked, and the tonkatsu. The waiter/owner was very nice, and the service was quick.
author: Annie K.

description: I don't think the other reviewer gets this place.  Yes, this place is run by a Burmese owner but it doesn't distract from this place at all.  I've been here twice now and this place delivers value.  It's undiscovered.  Where in San Francisco, can you get a delicious Japanese meal for $8.50?  You get miso soup, two entree selection, and a small salad.  The entrees include beef teriyaki, chicken teriyaki, tonkatsu, saba ship, shrimp tempura, etc...  It's not gourmet but it's homestyle.  I'm not Japanese so I am not going to make any claims about if it's like my Osaka mama's cooking but it's better than your typical J-town shop.  If you aren't hardcore Japanese, you won't complain either.  You can go to McDonald's and pay the same amount.  The owners are friendly and never up sell you.  Their $8.50 dinner/lunch deals are simply awesome.  Great place to eat on your own or with some friends.  Don't try and impress your date here unless she is low maintenance.
author: Laurence H.

description: My husband & I have been at Kui Shin Bo 2x during lunch time.  I am Asian and was exposed to eating traditional Japanese food.  I decided to give this place a 5 star rating.  Does the owner or the staff need to be Japanese to serve good Japansese food?  As far as I can tell, my husband, who is Caucasian loves the Beef Teriyaki.  I've tasted Kui Shin Bo's Beef Teriyaki and I think that they've always been consistent with the quality and taste of the meat and teriyaki sauce.  The miso soup was good.  The meal came with miso soup that was very delightful.  We also had Agedashi Tofu, which, to me has very mild taste....and that's what it should be....tasty, mild flavors from the bonito flakes and agedashi sauce.  I had volcano roll....that was wonderful.  The sauce was just right...some places do get carried away with QPie mayo, not this place....the sauce was just the right amount.  The first time we came here, I had the spicy tuna roll....love it!  Spicy!  Just the way I want it.
author: Cynthia F.

description:
the service was friendly 
the menu is what you'd get in your average japanese restaurant in the US... your normal fare of bento box combos, teriyaki, katsu, ramen, udon, some sushi rolls...
i had tempura udon and an order of hamachi nigiri...
the prices are cheap so i'm sure that's what most people come here for...

we were a party of 6 so we took a long time before we actually ordered... then we were the last ones in the restaurant... yea we were 'that' table... but the staff never rushed us or anything... so we had a good time
author: charlotte s.

description: simple mom and pop sushi bar and restaurant. quality fish and this night some awesome kumamoto oysters from Washington state. my gawd, they were tasty! extra small for better flavor -personally picked by Taka, sushi chef and owner. hamachi, albacore, salmon, unagi, were all very well done. finished off with a special miso soup with prawn heads simmered in the broth for extra flava. as our Governator once said, "I'll be back!"
author: Jeff W.

description: Great prices. I had the $8.50 special, with vegetable tempura and tonkatsu. Generous portions. The only reason I'm taking a star off is the service was quite slow. They seem to have a very limited number of employees, and it seems like the kitchen is quite small as well.
author: David K.

description:
I live 5 min from j-town, and have skipped around the restaurants around the mall. This is one of my go-to places. Why? Excellent service, quiet atmosphere, good prices(daily special price) with good amounts of food for what you pay for, and I've always been satisfied with my meals!

My favorite choices: BBQ pork ramen & Baked salmon roll.
author: vanessa g.

description: YOU HAVE TO EAT HERE!  We stayed in San Francisco for 7 nights and ate at Kui Shin Bo 6 of the 7 nights - that is how much we loved it!  The only reason we didn't eat there every night was that it was closed on Monday!  We tipped 25% every night because the service was so good and the food was so cheap.  My husband loved the Katsu Don and had it twice.  I tried the fried oysters which were divine.  The best thing I had was probably the baked salmon caterpillar roll as it was so fresh and delicious.  The waiter was lovely and made suggestions based on what he knew we liked.  The specials board was AMAZING and the home made noodles were truly out of this world.  I never review restaurants but our experience at Kui Shin Bo was so excellent that I was compelled to write and encourage people to go.  This place is the whole package!
author: Cassandra A.

description: Yes - not the same Kuishimbo as before but I feel key recipes and methods of cooking have been passed down.  Their nabeyaki udon soup, salads, and miso for example.  Maybe not totally up to par as before but still competitive with many other restaurants in the area.   It then comes down to price that gets me to come here regularly.  Why would I pay twice as much in Japan town for equal or less quality.  In my opinion many items here are still better than the competition!  One negative though:  I don't eat any types of sushi here.  When it comes to raw fish, I just prefer to see a LOT more turnover and an actual sushi chef at the helm.
author: J M.

description:
While spending the day in Japantown yesterday, the lunch specials board outside of Kui Shin Bo caught out eye. $7.50 got you two of the different entree choices listed, plus rice, salad, and dessert. We noticed several groups of Japanese people inside eating, so we figured the food couldn't be too bad and $7.50 for lunch is a steal. 

My boyfriend had chicken katsu and ramen and I had chicken katsu and shrimp tempura. My boyfriend has been fighting a cold for several days now and he said the warmth of the ramen helped his sinuses out, and furthermore it tasted pretty good! We both liked the chicken katsu as well and my shrimp tempura were huge and yummy. Dessert was some fried banana pieces and a small scoop of vanilla ice cream for each of us, which was a nice way to end the meal.

Keep in mind, this place is definitely a no frills kind of restaurant. It's very unassuming from the outside (we probably would've passed right over it if it weren't for the special board catching our eye) and the inside is rather plain too, albeit traditional Japanese-looking. However, the food was good and served quickly, the service was good, and it was CHEAP, which is really what matters in the end.
author: Michael M.

description: Friendly, quiet (which is kind of weird, but might be nice if you're tired from walking and shopping), great prices and specials, convenient to Ichibankan too  But the sushi - not that amazing. Kind of chewy seaweed or something. Prob there is a four star dish here, but on our one visit I didn't find it, and there are a lot of other places here, so...
author: Zake S.

description:
Plus: Cheap prices
Minus: Equally cheap food ._.

Look $7.50 for two full sized items... i'm not really complaaaaining, but the udon had three things: soup, noodle, onions. That's it. The tempura had more batter than shrimp, enough that there was a layer of un fried batter between the crunchy stuff and the shrimp. Oh and the entire plate was swimming with grease, so much so that i didn't want to eat the pieces of tempura that were sitting on the bottom. It was kinda like biting into a vegetable covered in a sponge soaked with oil.

They also forgot our salad and miso soup sides but honestly we weren't really that eager to get them. 

Then again what was i expecting for $7.50? The quality of the food was like eating at the west field mall, ick.. but at least it wasn't over priced. Oh and the waiter was nice. But I think i'd rather splurge just a few dollars more for something i would actively want to finish.
author: Susan L.

description:
This place is so good, I often come and eat here at least 3 times a week.  Nestled in the corner of "The other Mall" in Japantown, this place has perhaps the BEST Japanese food in all of Japantown.  

My usual order will consist of one of the 5 specials on the board, ranging from squid nittsuke to expertly prepared grilled fish.  Everything comes out of the kitchen with blazing speed, and I've never gone wrong with anything I've ordered there.  

This restaurant is very consistent with a restaurant you'd find lining one of the back alleys in Japan.  Quailty food, reasonable prices, and a friendly chef/owner.
author: Eric K.

description: For $2.50, the nigiri didn't taste bad at all. Salmon nigiri esp was fresh  and delicious. The knife work of the lady chef left a bit to be desired but this is a good deal in JapanTown. Green tea costs an extra $1 per person unfortunately. Would like to try their don next time.
author: M Y.

description:
Love the food, great service, and cheap.  We had 10 main dishes, from the value meal, and named rolls.  I really can't figure out why it was so dead, but then it looked like the entire wing of Japantown was dead, so, guilt by association?  Anyway, it was quiet when we showed up ~ 1 pm for lunch on a Sunday.  Service was very attentive and quick.  Towards the end, there were 4 tables and the owner/manager/whatever was still very attentive to us.   Reading the various Yelp reviews, it appears there was a major change last year?  I would have no problem recommending a second chance (if not first) to anyone.  

I did find some of the reviews amusing, and I do have one observation:  I love Girl Scout cookies, but I don't think they are made by (or of) Girl Scouts.  Does it really matter the ethnicity of the cook in a Japanese restaurant?
author: Al V.

description: STOP ALL PRESS!!! Kuishinbo's owner/chef sold the restaurant! The original owner is still there, but I'm told he's been hired by the new management during the transition. FOOD IS NOT THE SAME!! It's quite bad, actually. All the old patron have stopped going there apparently. I went there last night and the familiar grandmas and grandpas who used to hang out there every night were nowhere to be found. Rumor is, the original owner/chef is looking for another location in the city to start another restaurant in the near future. I'll post on Yelp! again once I find out more.
author: Kenji H.

description: My impression is that customers come here because of the low price and you get what you pay for.  I worked in the Kanda district in Tokyo for many years and know Kui Shin Bo deserves no better than two stars.  I would not recommend this restaurant to my friends and family.
author: Scott B.

description: I went here due to a debacle at another restaurant in Japantown and it was quite disappointing. The dressing tasted like bad thousand island and the beef teriyaki was off. My friend had ramen which was heavily seasoned (though the noodles in the ramen were excellent). My California roll tasted delicious fresh avocado, cucumber and faux crab but was falling apart on my plate. Not somewhere I'd go again.
author: Kelly O.

description: I've been going to this restaurant for years, and the service never bothers me because the food is so good and usually the lady is nice to me.  I think she really does warm up to regulars.
author: K M.

description:
I ventured to this resturant as per Toro E's advise, and just wanted to thank you for the suggestion. It was much appreciated! Made our trip to Japantown worth the drive - after running some errands at stonestown, all the way on the other side of the city. We both had items from the specials menu and it was a smart decision. I had the tuna tonkatsu, and bf had the curry udon. the tuna deep fried cutlets were so tender. The eggs, thier consistency and flavoring was the next best thing about the dish.. it was excellent with the thin layer of rice beneath it to balance out the flavor. I had a taste of the BF's udon. the udon itself could be better. But it was served in a light broth that was curry flavored. Not too thick - just the way we like it - made up for where the udon noodle consistency lacked in. We were very impressed - bf more so than i, becuase he's had his share of japanese food so he can relate his experiences better than i could.. 

I was a little let down with the notorious rumor of bad service, because we were treated very nicely. The wifey waitress was kind. But then again, we didnt ask for much or troubled her much to begin with. She even waved and smiled while we left. 

The portions here are huge. I had food coma after driving home, and just passed out! But its a small price to pay. either that, or next time just order 1 entree, and split it.
author: Mai T.

description: I have to say that this was the worst sushi I have had in my life.  I ordered the sashimi plate and left almost all of it... some of the fish had a strange soapy taste that was just awful.  I tried some other dish ( cant remember the name... ginger pork maybe??) it wasn't bad.  But it still couldn't take the nasty taste of the fish out of my mouth.  I certainly won't be going back.
author: kim r.

description: Service was slow! There were 3 other couples dining in the restaurant and I could feel the tension as we all waited for our orders to arrive. The sushi wasn't the freshest and their selection was very limited. No Uni or Toro. The $7.50 combo special was okay, all I can say is you get what you pay for. Overall, I was disappointed but, it was a cheap dinner and we didn't get sick.
author: J C.

description: I'm not saying this just because my family is good friends with the owners of this restaurant. I'm saying this because this is how I truly feel about Kui Shin Bo. The food is awesome, the atmosphere gives you a family feeling, and the inside gives you a feel like you're in a restaurant in Japan. I grew up in Japantown and whenever I go there, I like going to Kui Shin Bo for dinner. If you want to feel like you're in Japan &  you want great food, go to Kui Shin Bo!!!
author: Stacy S.

description: They just changed ownership and the previous owner stayed on as the sushi chef but the food isn't really the same.
author: JaM W.

description: My family must have eaten here at least 30x plus and everything is excellent, BUT DON'T ASK FOR ANYTHING EXTRA. If wasabi, ponzu sauce, and anything you want to have doesn't come with the meal already - DON'T ASK FOR IT!  you're not going to get it anyway.... remember the soup nazi on Seinfeld?
author: HRH S.

description:
Down-to-earth, non-american-ized Japanese home cooking.

They have a number of special combos that change everyday ranging between $10~$13 in price. I have yet to try anything from their menu because I can't help but order one of these de jour meals whenever I stop by.

They are located in a corner of the second floor of the east-most building in Japan Town. The atmosphere is quiet and calm because they are far from where the bulk of the shops and restaurants are.
author: Keisuke O.

description: The service and the place itself was fine but everything I ordered was bland, EVERYTHING. This place leaves me completely indifferent.
author: Jordan A.

description: Clean, ok service (didn't refill water or ask how food was) but from the other reviews I assume service is something you don't expect here.  Good sized portions. My udon was pretty good but not amazing. The shrimp tempura was tasteless, but the vegetables were good. My friend got the ginger pork that came with a small salad and miso soup and rice. Said it was really good. Prices are average.
author: buttercup r.

description: Just another ordinary place in j-town.  Was highly confused with their menu as it was half Japanese and half something else.  Lots of their specials were only on the white board outside the restaurant...and no sushi menu was presented.  Okay, it was also hot, and no fan, so not off to a good start.  We did manage to order sushi and some udon stuff, and it was surprisingly okay.  But, need some kind of "asian" atmosphere for the sushi to taste better.  Staff, was pleasant, but not in any way making the place feel Japanese.  Not exactly a repeat place.
author: Joe T. C.

description: After the BFF and I searched for a place to eat, this was the lucky winner! Not to mention, it had its very own Yelp sticker proudly displayed on the front door...so we knew this would be good! Like always, we try to be adventurous, try to try something new, and usually that takes us awhile to do so luckily the server (who was very nice) recommended their 2 item combo special. He recommended the Ramen soup and salmon. OMG! I have to say that was the best ramen soup I have ever had. Forget your .99 cent ramen noodles you can make at home--this was delish! The broth was simple but flavorful, accompanied by green onion and half a hard boiled egg. Soooooooo good. The salmon was moist and the sauce was just right.  We knew it was good because we hardly talked to each other while we were eating it...lol. Oh, and we didn't see that it would come with FREE dessert! Score! You can't go wrong with Free dessert! Ice cream and a piece of fried banana fritter. At the end of the day, it was a good day...tummys full and satisfied and we didn't break our budget. I'll be back indeed.
author: Mel P.

description:
More good news! Taka san was thinking that he might change to a different place but now has decided to that staying there might be fine =)
There is also a new additional menu for Happy Hour! Like a tradional Ippin Ryori style ( plate-by-plate ) $1.99 Nigiri sushi and Special Sushi Rolls besides being able to offer the regular menu. ((2-5pm everyday)).
They also no longer close between Lunch and Dinner so they are open Tuesday thru Sunday  11:30am- 9pm!
Still, if you would like to taste what people have in Japan the Special Board is extremely helpful ( not the same usual fare of the genre). If you really look closely at the menu you may notice that there are also some things that you do not find very often though you can still get the usual japanese american offerings if that is what you are seeking.
I am very happy that this place is back on track- I am sure it will once again be a favorite!!!!
author: RojiFox Q.

description: My favorite Japanese restaurant in the city, I've probably eaten here 25 times.  Has very good sushi, but I'm usually going for the other dishes like grilled mackerel or beef donburi or fried oysters.  Has a good range of everyday Japanese fare.
author: John T.

description: BEST FRIED CALAMARI I have ever had!  VERY tender, light, just enough buttery flavor.  Amazing price for the special - only $7.50 and had wonderful calamari & tonkatsu which came with rice, miso & "salad".  Waiter was very nice & attentive, apologized for the wait because they only had one chef & we were there with a VERY large group.  Tasted my kid's ramen & it was also the best I'd tasted.  We will definitely go back, that is for sure!
author: P F.

description: the food was tasty (esp the pork donburi), but the service was so bizarre i thought we were on candid camera. it started when we asked for some extra plates. man-lady waitress refused, saying they don't have any more bowls and plates. uh... wtf? next we asked for some extra wasabi, since we only got a pea-sized smidgen to begin with. she said it would be extra charge. ! and then when she came to refill our tea, she only filled the teacups of half the table (the others remained completely empty). 4 star food, but the service was so ridiculous i'll have to knock off a star.
author: annie c.

description: great authentic meals. my favorite is chirashi deluxe. the combination of seafood always changes depending on whats fresh that day, making the dish a pleasant delicious surprise each time. warm and relaxed atmosphere. highly recommend
author: alisa o.
